dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A big, rich, powerhouse all-white high school located nea the freeway into Cape Town. The RUGBY FIELDS are immacula FIFTEEN YEAR OLD BOYS in striped rugby jerseys train with total intensity under the critical eye of the COACH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right ACROSS THE BOUNDARY FENCE from the rugby fields is area of WASTE LAND leading up to the freeway. There, BLAC AND "COLORED" (MIXED-RACE) BOYS of the same age play a lo game of soccer with a tennis ball. Most of them have bare feet and threadbare, dirty clothes, most of them are noticeably smaller and skinnier than the white boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two cultures, separated by more than the high boundary fe

dialogues.speaker: SUPER TITLE
dialogues.text: A COMMOTION ON THE FREEWAY intrudes on the soccer game. Horns honking, cars pull over onto the shoulder, people j out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lead by police motorbikes, then patrol cars, a white Merc approaches, heading towards Cape Town. Whoever is in the Mercedes has stopped traffic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The soccer players abandon their game and run for the freeway, whistling and shouting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rugby players are more disciplined -- or obedient -- do not acknowledge the commotion until the convoy passes right by them. The coach shakes his head in disgust.

dialogues.speaker: HIGH SCHOOL BOY
dialogues.text: Who is it, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's that terrorist, Mandela. They let him out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember this day, boys. It's the day our country went to the dogs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A short, STOCK-FOOTAGE MONTAGE which spans the tumultuous four years between NELSON MANDELA'S release from prison a his inauguration as President of South Africa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Footage would include:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - Mandela's release from prison - negotiations with the apartheid regime - scenes of white fear and emigration - the horrifying sectarian violence leading up to the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - the khaki-clad AWB (Afrikaner right wing) attack on the World Trade Center (where negotiations were taking place) - the lifting of economic sanctions and cultural boycotts - the lifting of the international ban on the Springbok r team and immediate Test match losses to New Zealand and Australia. - popular black leader Chris Hani's assassination by whit

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - black retaliation - Mandela's frantic intervention to keep the country from going up in flames - the election itself, with those incredible images of thousands and thousands of people, black and white, linin patiently, some to vote for the first time in their lives - the African National Congress victory - Mandela's inauguration as President, where he delivers

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Never, never and never again shall it be that this beautiful land will again experience the oppression of one by another, and suffer the indignity of being the skunk of the world."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As APPLAUSE FADES ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dark. We can make out the FORM OF A TALL MAN SLEEPING ALO at the very edge of the big bed, as if not wanting to rum the blankets too much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the bedside table, the clock clicks from 4:59 to 5:00. The man's eyes open in the dark, instantly awake. He reac out, switches on the light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NELSON ROLIHLAHLA MANDELA, 76, sits up and gets out of be one movement. He has the physical vigor and energy of someone twenty years younger. 3.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The second he is up, he turns around and makes his bed, leaving it as flawlessly smooth as a hospital bed. Or a prison bunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For this is the discipline of twenty seven years behind b

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dressed in a tracksuit and cross-trainers, Mandela comes the stairs and heads for the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a nice, big house but it is amazingly modest for President of a wealthy nation, and arguably the most famo man on the planet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela steps outside, closes his front door quietly, tak moment to savor the air. It is bone dry and cold -- typic conditions in the Highveld at this time of year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is so quiet that, for a moment, it seems as if Mandela completely alone in the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The big yard is fenced. There is a small GUARD HOUSE at t driveway gate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When Mandela steps away from the house, A UNIFORMED SOUTH AFRICAN POLICEMAN IN THE GUARDHOUSE pushes the button tha opens the gate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When the gate begins to open we see that there are TWO GR BMWs parked either side of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LINGA MOONSAMY comes to full alert as the gate opens. He a big, scowling man dressed in a suit. He checks the load a pistol, tucks it into his shoulder holster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here he comes. Like clockwork.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It makes him such an easy target. 4.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behind Linga, in the back seat, sits JASON TSHABALALA, a naturally tense and suspicious man. Both of them are holl eyed, exhausted, running on adrenaline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They get out of the BMW, fast and quiet. This does not lo good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Mandela walks out through the gate, Jason and Linga intercept him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (traditional greeting in

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see you, father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela's face comes alive as he smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (without breaking stride) Morning boys. How are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason is Mandela's head of personal security, Linga his number one bodyguard. They are both former "terrorists", they are utterly devoted to Mandela.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're sharp, Madiba.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good ... good. And how's your mother doing, Linga?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's much better, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela picks up the pace. Jason and Linga fall back, so that they are a few steps behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They share a quick look. They hate this walk. It scares them. There's no way for it to be anything but completely unsanitary, from a security point of view.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SMALL DELIVERY VAN drives really fast, blows through st signs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela strides along the big, wide, tree-lined streets. Jason and Linga shadow him, eyes and ears alert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up ahead, we see a SMALL, UPSCALE AREA OF SHOPS AND RESTAURANTS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela, Jason and Linga reach the shopping area. Dark, deserted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANOTHER ANGLE of the shops as the small van turns onto th street with a squeal of tires.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SLIDING DOOR on the van IS OPENED from inside. Too da to see in. Ominous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela, Jason and Linga pass a HUGE POSTER OF MANDELA in window of CORNER GROCERY. Mandela does not react to this giant picture of himself, Jason and Linga do, proudly --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (A GENERAL NOTE: starting with the window of this grocery there are pictures of Mandela everywhere. Magazine covers newspaper centerfolds, T-shirts, children's art -- as if make up for all the time Mandela's image and words were banned.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- until they HEAR THE SOUND OF THE VAN tearing towards t They turn, SEE HEADLIGHTS VEERING TO THEIR SIDE OF THE STREET. 6.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOTH MEN DROP THEIR HANDS TO THEIR GUNS. Linga steps in front of Mandela, shielding him, Jason steps out wide, re for anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela is completely calm. The van screeches to a halt j past them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A GUY jumps out of the van holding a tied BUNDLE OF NEWSPAPERS, which he drops with a thump at the grocery do The guy doesn't see them. The delivery van is gone before the newspapers stop moving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela heads for the newspapers -- he wants to see the headlines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason and Linga take their hands off their guns, but they not relax. These are dangerous times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GO IN ON THE TOP NEWSPAPER, which shows a PHOTO OF THE INAUGURATION, and the following words, in Afrikaans: HE C

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does it say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It says, "He can win an election, but can he run a country?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not even one day on the job and they're after you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a legitimate question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela turns and marches for home. Jason and Linga fall behind him. In the east, the first milky hint of day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The house is now bustling with activity. A pretty member the KITCHEN STAFF sets a single place at the head of a bi formal dining table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A LADY CHEF stirs the porridge, a KITCHEN ASSISTANT cuts fresh fruit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela's PERSONAL SECRETARY, MARY marches out of her sma office with a STACK OF CORRESPONDENCE AND FIVE NEWSPAPERS places them neatly next to the table setting. 7.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside, Mandela is surrounded by men. Inside, he has surrounded himself with women of all shapes, colors and a to make up for twenty seven years without.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MANDELA SHAVES UPSTAIRS IN THE BATHROOM. The razor is dul

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela opens drawers looking for another. He opens a dra that is empty but for a WOMAN'S BEADED BRACELET, broken a shedding tiny colored beads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela looks for it for a moment, then closes the drawer looks at himself in the mirror. Mostly, Mandela's face is warm, animated, energetic and this is how we see him, alm all the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, sometimes, his face can be a remote, sphinx-like mas that conceals all emotion, all feeling. This is his priso face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the face that looks back at Mandela, right now, i the mirror. It is the face of a man whose long, hard jour has marked his very soul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Expressionless, Mandela shaves himself with the dull razo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OVER, a COCK CROWS and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- a QUICK SERIES OF SHOTS, as the RAINBOW NATION WAKES U

dialogues.speaker: TV ANNOUNCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Today marks the beginning of a new era in South Africa --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the bush to the cities, from shanty towns to ocean-f mansions, PEOPLE START THEIR DAY.

dialogues.speaker: TV ANNOUNCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: -- as President Mandela takes office in Pretoria, facing issues that range from economic stagnation and unemployment to rising crime --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some start the day with a tea tray placed next to their b by discreet black hands, some with nothing more than brow river water and half a fire-blackened ear of corn for breakfast. 8.

dialogues.speaker: TV ANNOUNCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: -- while at the same time balancing black aspirations --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- with white fears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Click! The TV is turned off by MR. PIENAAR (late 40's) in his very modest, blue-collar house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never thought I'd see the day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Pienaar turns and addresses his son, FRANCOIS PIENAAR 27, a big, blond, almost-handsome man with a fighter's fa and mangled ears. Brutal toughness and honor in his features. A powerful physical presence, possibly dangerou Francois drips with sweat, wears running clothes. Whateve he does, he is strong, fit and driven.

dialogues.speaker: MR. PIENAAR
dialogues.text: I feel sorry for you, son. You've got your whole life ahead of you. What's it going to be like now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS. PIENAAR (late 40's) enters holding some kind of PROT SHAKE for Pienaar.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. PIENAAR
dialogues.text: Don't be so gloomy. (handing over shake) I added vitamins -- there's a horrible flu bug going around. Tell Nerine when you get home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, ma.

dialogues.speaker: MR. PIENAAR
dialogues.text: I'm telling you, Francois -- look at Angola, look at Mozambique. Look at Zimbabwe. We're next. They're going to take our jobs and drive us into the sea. Just you wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Magnificent, sweeping government buildings made of carved African field stone, with an Italian tiled roof, situated a hill overlooking Pretoria. The seat of power.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Today, the entrance is mobbed with a huge, joyous, multi- racial throng, plus news crews from all over the world. L of new South African flags evident.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We move through the throng and swoop up into the air, so we can soar along the outside of the building and LOOK THROUGH THE WINDOWS into the offices of state --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- where people who worked for the De Klerk regime are packing up, in anticipation of being booted out by the Mandela regime. These characters run the gamut from littl old Afrikaner tea ladies in tears, to the stoic fossils o grand apartheid. They are all white. A good third of the offices are already deserted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The deserted offices have open doors. Through a window, through an open door, we see Mandela and his bodyguards striding down a Union Building hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We swoop in through the window --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and catch up with the new President. Mandela is regal a magnificent tailored suit. Jason in front, Linga behind

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PORTRAITS of the architects and champions of apartheid lo down sternly on them as they pass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They pass a WORKER hanging a PORTRAIT OF MANDELA next to of De Klerk, the previous President.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON LINGA, as he smiles at that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela, on the other hand, looks into the empty offices, into the offices being packed up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up ahead, the double doors to the OFFICE OF THE PRESIDENT are closed. Jason speeds up, opens them, pokes his head i then opens the doors wide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with great pride) After you, Mr. President. 10.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela's offices are fronted by a LARGE RECEPTION AREA, already filled with PEOPLE WAITING TO SEE HIM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To one side are his CHIEF OF STAFF'S SUITE of offices, to other side, the SMALL PRESIDENTIAL SECURITY OFFICE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beyond these are MANDELA'S SECRETARIES, TYPISTS AND ASSISTANTS -- his gatekeepers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beyond that is the inner sanctum, MANDELA'S OWN OFFICE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The phones are ringing off the hook. Fax machines are chattering. Everyone wants a piece of Mandela.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela enters, Jason and Linga behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning everybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BARBARA MASEKELA, Mandela's CHIEF OF STAFF (and now Ambassador to the U.S.), emerges from her office, carryin arm load of files, folders and papers --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara, good morning. You've had your hair done. I like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- accompanies Mandela back towards his office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Madiba. We need to talk about your cabinet appointments and ministers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me one moment, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara waits outside Mandela's office, as he enters ahea her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela stands in the middle of his office, takes a momen savor where he is. 11.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then, he takes off his jacket, hangs it up and is ready f work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- please assemble the staff for me. Whoever has not already left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right now? All of them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's left of the UNION BUILDING STAFF are packed into t DINING ROOM. White faces, bitter and resentful. Waiting t be fired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the glass doors, THEY SEE MANDELA APPROACHING DOW THE HALLWAY, Linga and Jason with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here he comes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wants the satisfaction of firing us himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stand up straight, determined to receive the ax with pride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Linga and Jason amp up when they see the room full of restless Afrikaners. At the STAFF DINING ROOM DOOR, Mande turns to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like you to stay out here, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, Madiba ... 12.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I cannot talk to them if I'm hiding behind men with guns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela opens the doors and enters. Jason and Linga stay outside ... just.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela enters, smiles -- gets not one smile in return.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gooie more almal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does he think greeting us in Afrikaans makes this any sweeter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some of you may know who I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This gets a few bitter chuckles. Mandela is at this best just talking to people, like this. Only, he doesn't just talk to them, he wades in amongst them, shaking hands and making individual contact as he speaks to all of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning ... how are you ... thank you for coming at such short notice ... etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela is a continual security nightmare. You can see th tension on Jason and Linga's faces as he disappears into throng.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When Mandela reaches the middle of the room, he stops sha hands, and turns slowly as he talks to everybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't help noticing the empty offices as I came to work today. And all the packing boxes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One black man, surrounded by a throng of serious white fa 13.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, of course, if you want to leave, that is your right. And if you feel in your heart that you cannot work with your new government, then it is better that you do leave, right away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can be tough and blunt, when necessary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But if you are packing up because you fear that your language, or the color of your skin, or who you served previously, disqualifies you from working here now, I am here to tell you, have no such fear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wat is verby is verby. What's past is past. We look to the future, now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is not what they expected to hear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need your help. We want your help. If you would like to stay, you will be doing your country a great service.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela pauses, to look at the faces. They are receptive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ask only that you do your jobs to the best of your abilities, and with good hearts. I promise to do the same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we can manage that, our country will be a shining light in the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason and Linga are right outside the glass doors, lookin and listening. Jason shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wants to win them over, one damn boer at a time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela heads back through to his office, Barbara, Mary a other assistants forming a phalanx around him. Linga peel off, goes into the security office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason stands at the desk of one of the assistants (JESSIE waits for her to finish a call, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Molo, sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's still morning?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason grins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you get a chance, can we see the schedule for the month? We need to plan security.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jessie's phone rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Office of the President, good morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jessie waves Jason off. He crosses to the security office enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once he closes the door behind him, Jason shows his fatig Linga is feet-up on the sofa, sucking on a cup of coffee. Three more bodyguards -- SAM, KWEZI and WINSTON -- slump chairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason grabs coffee, sits at his desk, puts his feet up wi groan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need more men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you talk to Barbara about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yesterday. 15.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A knock at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's Jessie, with the schedule.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come in, beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens -- but what enters is not beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FOUR BIG WHITE COPS in suits enter, Special Branch writte all over them. ETIENNE VAN ECK, HENDRICK BOOYENS, GEORGE WILLEM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bodyguards stand up like junk yard dogs protecting th territory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Jason Tshabalala?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's me. Am I under arrest?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Etienne snaps out a crisp salute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain Van Eck and team reporting for duty, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hendrick, George and Willem snap out salutes. Their milit deportment contrasts strongly with the less rigid body language of the black bodyguards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What duty?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're the Presidential bodyguard. We've been assigned to this office. (holding out a sheet of

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here are our orders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason takes the orders, studies them, face increasingly angry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're Special Branch, right? 16.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hendrick nods, sternly. Linga, Sam, Kwezi and Winston rea to that -- there is a long and brutal history between the and the Special Branch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll see that they've been signed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care if they're signed or --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason does a double-take when he sees the signature on th orders: NELSON R. MANDELA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason storms out, holding the orders. The four black bodyguards seethe with hostility. The four white bodyguar stare straight ahead, refusing to give ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela and Barbara look over a position paper on somethi or other. When Jason knocks and enters, they pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry to disturb you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look agitated, Jason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's because I've got four Special Branch cops in my office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What have you done?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me? Nothing. They say they're the Presidential bodyguard. They have orders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Signed by you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. They've had special training, those boys -- with the SAS. And lots of experience. They protected De Klerk. 17.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, but --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You asked for more men, didn't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, but --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In public, when people see me, they see my bodyguards, too. You represent me, directly. The rainbow nation starts here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reconciliation starts here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reconciliation? Madiba, not long ago they tried to kill us! Maybe even these four guys. They tried and, often, they succeeded!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Linga, Sam, Winston and Kwezi stare down Etienne, Hendric George and Willem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela stares at Jason in an entirely different way -- w wisdom, compassion and sympathy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forgiveness starts here, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela lets that sink in for a moment. He knows he asks something very difficult, but he demands it of himself to even greater degree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forgiveness liberates the soul. It removes fear. That is why it is such a powerful weapon, Jason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please try it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason exhales. He isn't remotely ready to forgive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Madiba. Sorry to disturb you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason turns, leaves. Barbara shakes her head at Mandela.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ask a lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only what is necessary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Jason -- very upset -- walks back to security, Jessie holds out a file for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two copies of the schedule.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason snatches the file, keeps walking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Jessie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When he reaches the security office door, Jason walks rig past, keeps going, has to make a full loop of the recepti area, just to get himself together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even so, when he gets back to the security office door, J pauses, gathers himself to do something that he knows he' going to hate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Things haven't eased up one little bit inside the office. The silence is deafening. Jason enters, looks them all ov His face is grim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can we get rid of these guys, now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason flashes a look at Linga, then -- and this hurts him visibly -- he holds out one of MANDELA'S SCHEDULES to Etienne. 19.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is his schedule for the next month. Let's look it over for duty assignments.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Linga and the others are shocked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason, I have to talk to you. Outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Linga virtually pulls Jason out of the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just outside the Security Office door, so they keep their voices low.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can we trust them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't. (heading back in) This is what Madiba wants, okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not okay for Linga, judging by the expression on his face

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When Jason and Linga enter, Etienne looks up from Mandela schedule.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are there any special orders or conditions?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Yes. Madiba gets upset if you don't smile when you push people out of the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seriously? 20.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, seriously. It's the new South Africa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madiba?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The President's clan name. It's what we call him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The new bodyguards share a look. They're not comfortable with "Madiba".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll call him Mr. President.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason lifts the schedule.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's get through this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still upset and hostile, the black bodyguards look over Jason's shoulder, the white bodyguards look over Etienne' at the month's schedule.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Apartheid is by no means dead in this cramped little offi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both teams study and discuss the schedule -- (shop talk t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Etienne shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's he going to do all this? When does he take a break?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He says he rested enough in prison.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason recoils at something he sees on the last page of th schedule.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's a headache.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? 21.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A rugby match at Loftus Versfeld. British Lions against the Springboks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's going to be a headache for the Lions, that's for sure. We're going to donder them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care about the game. I care that the President'll be so exposed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To thousands of drunken --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- sports fans?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Sports fans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who didn't vote for him. Who probably hate him. Who came out of the womb with guns in their hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A huge, raucous crowd, almost entirely white and male. Ma wearing the Springbok green and gold. Widespread evidence drinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lots of OLD SOUTH AFRICAN FLAGS -- the blue, white and or apartheid flag -- make a defiant statement against the NE SOUTH AFRICAN FLAGS ringing the stadium.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the field, THE RUGBY TEAMS ASSEMBLE and face each othe two lines. The BRITISH LIONS in their white on white with black and red trim, the SPRINGBOKS in their green and gol

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like their supporters, the Springboks are all white, but one man, who is "colored" (mixed race). 22.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big, tough, brutal-looking men. Scary. (We may or may not notice Francois Pienaar, standing at the head of the line Springboks.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the entrance of the tunnel onto the field, LOTS OF COP blue South African Police uniforms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behind the line of cops, in the tunnel, we find JASON AND THE OTHER BODYGUARDS but for Linga. They are keyed-up, intense -- none more so than Jason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting against the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want your eyes on the crowd at all times. We're staying in the middle of the field. He's going to walk out, shake hands, walk back. Nothing else. Got it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They nod. They are like the players at game time, only th stakes are much higher. Jason looks deeper into the tunne straightens up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here we go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela strides down the tunnel towards them, wearing a d suit. Big crowds energize him. His eyes are alive with excitement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One pace behind him, like a huge, dark shadow, comes Ling

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela gives Jason a look, Jason nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We follow Mandela and the bodyguards out of the tunnel --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- onto the field, towards the waiting teams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd rise to their feet. Lots of them jeer Mandela, lots cheer. All the old South African flags are waved at defiantly -- plus some new ones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela waves to them all, smiling proudly. To him, a cro is an opportunity to make new friends. But he stays in th center of the field. 23.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason and crew are hyper-alert, a human fence around Mand

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela reaches the rugby players.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Waiting for him at the head of the Springbok line, wearin the NUMBER 6 JERSEY and captain's armband, is FRANCOIS PIENAAR. Now we know what he does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela extends his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good luck, captain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela shakes hands down the line of Springboks, then returns, shaking hands with the British Lions. Quick, perfunctory handshakes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Mandela does this, we take BODYGUARD POV SNAPSHOTS of crowd, increasingly keyed-up and restless. Time to play rugby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela finishes, waves to the crowd, and begins the walk along the center of the field, back to the tunnel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crowd noise increases. They know the opening whistle is about to blow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then, Mandela sees something in the crowd, at field level

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WITHOUT WARNING, MANDELA CHANGES DIRECTION, heads towards this group, towards a wall of his former -- and perhaps current -- enemies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON JASON: shit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay with him. 24.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With his bodyguards scrambling to stay in position, Mande reaches the stands, hand outstretched, leans into the cro

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you for honoring our new flag!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some shake his hand, some -- very pointedly -- do not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd noise takes on an ugly undertone -- Mandela is delaying the rugby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela is undeterred. He's into this one-on-one outreach He turns, looks for more hands to shake --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and Jason steps in between Mandela and the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're delaying the rugby, Madiba.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes, of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela gives one last wave, turns away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he does, SOMEONE WINDS UP AND THROWS SOMETHING from th stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason and Etienne catch the movement, whirl, too late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN ORANGE WHIZZES PAST MANDELA'S HEAD, explodes juicily o the field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela didn't see it, doesn't react. If anything, his sm widens as he heads across the field. The bodyguards close around him protectively, get him back to the tunnel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason signals for extra bodyguards to escort Mandela all way up to his box. Hendrick, the biggest, leads the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason stays in the tunnel, along with Etienne. Both men a in a muck sweat, adrenaline coursing through them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't you stop him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next time, you try. 25.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does he do that sort of thing all the time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ask my ulcer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good thing that was just an orange.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And good thing he never saw it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, he saw it. He sees everything. (rubbing his ulcer) I hate rugby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two international front rows come together with bone- crunching force.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huge, violent men grunt like bulls. The crowd roar vibrat the stadium. The scrum -- a phalanx of eight men locked together against eight -- wheels, buckles, then steadies under the watchful eye of the referee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fanning out behind each scrum are the backs -- faster, mo glamorous players who will run with the ball, or kick it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Lions scrumhalf thrusts the ball into the maw of the scrum, the huge men lock up against each other with maxim force.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ball comes out the back of the Lions' scrum, the scrumhalf dive-passes it away to the backs, who flick it laterally to the wing, with lightning speed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wing lofts a delicate kick just over the onrushing Springbok defenders. The Lions charge the ball, which bounces erratically --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- right into the hands of the man who kicked it. One las burst of speed, one quick juke to avoid a desperation tac and the wing scores in the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the Lions kicker gets ready to convert the try, we fin the Springboks huddling under their goal posts, hands on their hips, stunned. 26.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the center of the huddle Pienaar bleeds behind his gum guard as, furiously, he tries to inject some fire into hi team.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Concentrate, dammit! Focus! We can beat these guys if we play our game, not theirs!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON PIENAAR, as he realizes he is not getting through. The is dullness, shock in his player's eyes --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- which all lift to the heavens as the CONVERSION KICK S through the uprights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We FOLLOW THE KICK as it drops past a GIANT SCOREBOARD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STAY ON THE SCOREBOARD as it registers the conversion and shows the score: LIONS - 10 SPRINGBOKS - 0

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the VIP box, Mandela turns his back on the field as th game restarts beneath him and continues in the background He has BINOCULARS around his neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shall we work while we watch? We have lots of promises to keep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara sits to his right, with her ever-present files an folders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, we do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary pours tea at the back of the box. Linga stands two steps behind Mandela.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Mandela's left, sits the PRESIDENT OF SOUTH AFRICAN RU a small man with a small man's ruthlessness and drive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not too late, if the boys can just pick up their game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If they don't, heads will roll. This is unacceptable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on you bloody bastards! 27.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela's expression shows that he has a gentleman's dist for profanity. He turns to Barbara.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where do you want go first, for foreign investment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where the money is. America, England, Saudi Arabia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara makes notes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela lifts his BINOCULARS, but instead of looking at t rugby, he looks at the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MANDELA'S POV THROUGH BINOCULARS -- Mandela zeroes in on OLD SOUTH AFRICAN FLAG -- the apartheid flag. It is being held by the FOUR KHAKI-CLAD BOERS (FARMERS). Classic Sout African figures from the rural far north, they are alread drunk and suicidally depressed by the turn of events on t field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you see all the old apartheid flags? It's a disgrace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela lowers his binoculars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's also a constitutional right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Along with the apartheid anthem. I know. But it's time people moved on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela grunts, raises his binoculars again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MANDELA'S POV THROUGH BINOCULARS -- Mandela finds a SMALL KNOT OF BLACK SPECTATORS, holding the NEW SOUTH AFRICAN F and cheering ecstatically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at that. The whites are cheering for the Springboks, the blacks are cheering for the Lions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela lowers the binoculars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We did that on the island, you know. We supported anyone but the `boks. It really irritated the warders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course it did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON MANDELA as he thinks about this for a moment, then lif his binoculars to look at the crowd again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MANDELA'S POV THROUGH BINOCULARS -- on the knot of black spectators, who leap to their feet, reacting to ACTION ON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- where the Lions score yet another try. This is an ass- whipping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The conversion sails over the `boks heads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The scoreboard clicks over to: LIONS - 20 SPRINGBOKS - O

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela lowers his binoculars, sets them aside, shakes hi head. He knows it's hopeless now. He turns to the Rugby President.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long until the World Cup?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About a year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Plenty of time for improvement. 29.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Rugby President can't take it. He stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. President -- I wouldn't get my hopes up. We're a damn disgrace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stomps out of the box, no doubt looking for someone to fire. Mandela gets back to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to go to India and Indonesia, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a knock at the luxury box door. Linga swings to face the door, alert, as a UNIFORMED DOORMAN opens it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The MINISTER OF SPORT (Steve Tshwete), enters.

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER OF SPORT
dialogues.text: Sorry I'm late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sits down in the empty chair to the right of Mandela.

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER OF SPORT
dialogues.text: How's it going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very badly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Minister of Sport checks the score, winces.

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER OF SPORT
dialogues.text: Maybe it's just as well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela shoots him a sharp look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER OF SPORT
dialogues.text: (bending close, talking

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've just been at a meeting of the National Sports Council executive. There's strong support to drop the Springbok emblem and colors altogether. (gesturing at the field) If they're playing badly, maybe its a good time to make a change. (with barely hidden

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MINISTER OF SPORT (cont'd) This could be the last time we have to look at the green and gold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Minister of Sport shoots a glance at Mandela, to see reaction to all this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela is deep in thought and completely unreadable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One last, bloody, violent bit of play -- then, mercifully the final whistle blows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Final score: LIONS - 32 SPRINGBOKS - 15.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Lions celebrate. The Springboks head off the field, heads down, shoulders bowed in defeat -- none more bitter disappointed or bloodier than Francois Pienaar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the stands, the unheard of happens -- the Springboks a booed by their own fans. Not by everybody, but by enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We STAY WITH THE `BOKS as they trudge across the field, t clatter along the concrete tunnel to their dressing room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The atmosphere is absolutely dismal as the men undress an shower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody catches anybody else's eye. Huge, powerful, pale bodies have been ploughed purple with rake marks, bruises roasties. Plus, one dark body -- that of CHESTER WILLIAMS skilled wing from the Cape, a reserved and private man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pienaar takes off his green and gold jersey, sits, begins taking off his cleats. His body hurts. He has been raked, scratched, bruised, and his ankle is swollen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A noble warrior, defeated.

dialogues.speaker: BOLAND BOTHA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Francois Pienaar's team came to Loftus Versfeld stadium this afternoon, unprepared and arrogant. 31.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meet BOLAND BOTHA as he tapes his commentary on the test match. He is an ex-Springbok player from the boycott year now turned ponderous, florid rugby commentator. He is a household name, and the last word on the state of the Springboks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They left 80 minutes later with their tails between their legs, like whipped mongrels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I, for one, am glad. Not because we lost, but because there's now no way to disguise the fact that we are completely and utterly unprepared to reenter the world of top-notch international rugby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boland defines the South African talent for pessimism and negativity.

dialogues.speaker: BOLAND BOTHA, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: The Rugby World Cup is now less than a year away, and I, for one, am relieved that we are the host nation, and therefore qualify automatically for the tournament. Because I'm not sure we would get in on merit alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Rugby President sucks on a rum and coke, watches Bola with one of his HENCHMEN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who gets the axe? Someone has to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No after-match party this night. Still depressed by the loss, Pienaar stays home with this fiancee NERINE. 32.

dialogues.speaker: BOLAND BOTHA, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: Pienaar's team played without discipline, without strategy and without courage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's trying to get them to drop me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's just bitter because the Springboks were boycotted when he played.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe, but people listen to what he says.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wearing pyjamas, dressing gown and slippers, Mandela mult tasks, watching Boland Botha and going through a pile of correspondence, scribbling notes or signing his name.

dialogues.speaker: BOLAND BOTHA, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: They brought shame upon our nation, and I, for one, can say without fear of contradiction, that today, these fifteen so-called men did not deserve to wear the hallowed green and gold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON MANDELA: a thought, an idea -- a big one -- is churnin his head. He grunts, turns off the TV, puts the correspondence aside, stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary enters with a glass of milk and some pills, on a tra

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's your muti. I warmed the milk tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're too good to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela takes his pills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your daughter called, to cancel her visit this weekend. 33.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela pauses, between pills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did she say why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, she didn't. (making it up) She said to tell you she was sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela nods, has a hard time swallowing his last pill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you need anything else tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, thank you. I'm going to bed. Good night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, Madiba. Sleep well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela smiles at her, but as soon as he is past her, the smile fades. As he climbs the stairs to his bedroom, his face becomes sadder and older and lonelier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IN HIS BEDROOM, Mandela pauses to take off his dressing g He looks at his bed. It is as smooth and as blank as a sh of paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He peels back the bedclothes at one corner, slides under and pauses for a moment while reaching for the light swit He switches off the light and lies down, still and straig

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The most popular man in the world starts and ends each da alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A very poor township outside Johannesburg. A stark remind of how much work Mandela has ahead of him. A STAMPEDE OF KIDS runs by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We FOLLOW THE KIDS and find a SMALL, BEAT-UP CHURCH. A no LINE OF THREADBARE KIDS leads from outside into the churc There is a pecking order in the line, based on size.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. COLEMAN, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: No pushing now! There's enough for everybody! 34.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At a table near the altar, the kids rummage through bags second-hand clothes under the watchful eye of MRS. COLEMA stout and charitable woman. Next to her, MRS. DLAMINI han out a lollipop and says --

dialogues.speaker: MRS. DLAMINI
dialogues.text: God bless you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- to each kid. The clothes and lollipops move fast, rhyt kept by Mrs. Dlamini's "God bless yous".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The last bag of clothes empties fast as the line of kids reduces until there is only ONE SMALL BOY (SIPHO) left an only one article of clothing. An old SPRINGBOK RUGBY PRACTISE JERSEY. Green and gold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sipho could use it. His clothes are more holes than anyth else. He looks at the Springbok jersey mournfully.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. COLEMAN
dialogues.text: You're a very lucky boy. It's a real Springbok practise jersey! It's a bit big, but it's warm and it'll last for ever!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sipho shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. COLEMAN
dialogues.text: It's yours, take it! Go on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sipho turns and leaves. Mrs. Coleman looks at Mrs. Dlamin completely confused.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. COLEMAN
dialogues.text: Why won't he take it?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. DLAMINI
dialogues.text: If he wears it, the others will beat him up.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. COLEMAN
dialogues.text: Because the Springboks are playing so badly?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. DLAMINI
dialogues.text: No. Because, for them, the Springboks still represent apartheid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eersterust is a settlement and conference location just outside Pretoria.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Today it is the location of a full membership meeting of National Sports Council, an ANC organization that is now governing body of all sports in South Africa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A banner draped across the conference center entrance tel us so: WELCOME NATIONAL SPORTS COUNCIL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An NSC FIREBRAND has the podium and the microphone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... and now for the next item on our agenda.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hall is jammed. Very few white faces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The NSC executive proposes a full membership vote on the following motion ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A ripple of anticipation goes through the delegates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... that as a prominent symbol of the apartheid era, the colors, emblem and name of the Springboks be eliminated immediately ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That causes a stir. The delegates understand how big this is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... and that all sports teams representing South Africa shall be known forthwith as the Proteas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excitement and noise level rises. The NSC Firebrand has t shout through his mike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We will submit this motion to a hand vote.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NSC FIREBRAND (cont'd) In the event of a close count, we will go to a written ballot. (the moment he's been

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The NSC firebrand shoots his clenched fist into the air. With a roar, the delegates respond, raising their fists. Unanimous. The Springboks are history.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANOTHER ANGLE, as ONE OF THE OLDER DELEGATES steps outsid make a call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At his desk, Mandela puts down his phone. Anger in his ey He slams both palms down hard on his desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both bodyguard units (minus Jason) are crammed into the s office. The black bodyguards murmur amongst themselves in Xhosa. (Ad-lib.) The white bodyguards talk Afrikaans (ad- lib).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No talk between the two units, only tension.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tension broken with a crash as JASON SLAMS THE DOOR OPEN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both units to the cars, right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grey BMW, armored grey Mercedes, grey BMW in a line at th entrance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason, Kwezi, Winston and Sam scramble out of the buildin and dive into the lead BMW.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Etienne, Hendrick, George and Willem dive into the traile 37.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brusque, scowling, Mandela marches towards the exit, shad by Linga, flanked by Barbara.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do I tell the Japanese trade delegation?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I delegate that decision to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want me to inform the VP?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We should at least include the Minister of Sport.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela heads out to the cars. Barbara has no choice but follow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ever the gentleman, Mandela ushers Barbara into the Merce As she gets in:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I strongly advise against doing this. Especially on your own. It ... it gives the impression of autocratic leadership.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela gets in, closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You risk alienating your cabinet and your party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your advice is duly noted, Barbara. 38.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madiba ... the people want this. They hate the Springboks. They don't want to be represented by a team they cheered against all their lives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I know. But in this instance the people are wrong. And it is my job as their elected leader to make them see that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela leans forward to talk to Linga.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you tell the boys that Madiba wants to go to Eersterust, very fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Linga murmurs into his radio. The convoy pulls out, very fast. Barbara makes one last plea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're risking your political capital. You're risking your future as our leader.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The day I am afraid to do that is the day I am no longer fit to lead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At least risk it for something more important than rugby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela looks out the window, says nothing, angry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela's convoy heads away from Pretoria, very fast.

dialogues.speaker: NSC FIREBRAND, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ... and in concluding this historic conference ... 39.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... brothers, sisters, comrades, we in the executive applaud your diligence and courage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The NSC Firebrand and the executive applaud the members. applause spreads until the hall rocks. They are all very pleased with themselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela's convoy roars in. Mandela is the first one out, Linga next.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason and crew scramble to cover the immediate area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kwezi opens the door for Barbara on the other side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela strides over to Jason, says something to him. Jas looks surprised, turns to Hendrick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Linga's customary scowl intensifies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the applause finally begins to diminish, the NSC Fireb turns and nods to a CHURCH CHOIR DIRECTOR, off to the sid

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The choir director brings his CHOIR onto the stage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brothers, sisters ... join us in our anthem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyone not standing, stands. The choir director raises hi hands. The choir inhales. Go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nkosi Sikelel' iAfrica etc (God Bless Africa) --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But before the first line is fully sung, an ASSISTANT rus out, whispers urgently into the NSC Firebrand's ear. 40.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Firebrand's eyes bug out in surprise. He crosses to t Choir Director, says something quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Choir Director stops the choir in mid-chorus. Consternation everywhere. What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brothers, sisters, members of the choir -- we would only interrupt such beautiful music for something truly important. In this case, for someone truly important. (beat, milking it) Please welcome President Mandela!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place goes berserk as Mandela enters, with Linga at h back, and -- surprise, surprise -- Hendrick Booyens leadi the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Face stern and unsmiling, Mandela walks the length of the hall towards the podium. The delegates press in towards them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANOTHER ANGLE - Jason coordinates security inside and out Lifts his radio to his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON HENDRICK, as his standard bad bastard scowl suddenly becomes a smile -- which scares the throng more than the scowl did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON LINGA, the same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANOTHER ANGLE - Barbara enters at the back of the hall, accompanied by Kwezi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela reaches the podium, turns looks out over the crow face thunderous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When they see his anger, the crowd quietens down quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brothers, sisters, comrades, I am here because I feel strongly that you made a decision today without sufficient information or foresight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lectures them like a headmaster. They don't like it. 41.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am aware of your earlier vote. I am aware that it was unanimous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nonetheless, I propose that we restore the Springboks. Restore their name, their emblem and their colors, immediately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Instant and complete silence in the hall. This is utterly unpopular. Shocked faces, especially from the executive a the NSC firebrand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON BARBARA, as she sees her worst political nightmare pla out in front of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me tell you why ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murmurs of disapproval and disagreement begin to rise. Mandela's going to have to row upstream on this one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... on Robben Island, in Pollsmoor Prison, my jailers were all Afrikaners.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For twenty seven years, I studied them. I learned their language, I read their history, I read their poetry. I had to know my enemy, in order to prevail against him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we prevailed, did we not? All of us here ... we prevailed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the first time, Mandela says something the crowd like

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our enemy is no longer the Afrikaner. They are our fellow South Africans, our partners in democracy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just as quickly, Mandela loses them again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And they treasure Springbok rugby. If we take that away, we lose them. We prove that we are what they feared we would be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have to be better than that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have to surprise them with compassion, with restraint, and generosity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The grumbling and disagreement becomes noticeably louder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I know. All the things they denied us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON HENDRICK, totally engrossed in his job, eyes sweeping across the crowd, feeling the tension.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But this is not the time to enjoy a moment's petty revenge. This is the time to build our nation using every single brick available to us - - even if that brick comes clothed in green and gold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd is growing more restless and rebellious by the moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LINGA is as alert as Hendrick, tuned in to the jumpy vibe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You elected me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You elected me to be your leader. Let me lead you now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is with me on this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's almost as if he's daring them to go against him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is with me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The murmuring becomes a dull roar of argument and disagreement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON BARBARA as she closes her eyes and lowers her head: th is a fiasco.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As delegates spill out of the conference hall, Mandela's convoy leaves as fast as it arrived. It almost looks as i they're fleeing. 43.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. Mandela looks exhausted, almost gaunt. Facing hi own people like that took it out of him. Barbara stares o the window, chewing her lip, totally stressed out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Linga heaves a great sigh, exhales a truckload of stress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason and his crew travel in stoic silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Similar silence from Etienne and crew. It seems like the silence of defeat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twelve votes. Twelve!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A luxury. All we needed was one more yes than no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if you hadn't got it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, as you know, I am an obedient party member.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara snorts disagreement. She is angry at her boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Madiba, but we've got problems everywhere we look. Housing, food, jobs, crime, our currency. You can't keep interrupting affairs of state to placate a minority.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, I must. This minority still controls the army, the police, and the economy. Without them, we cannot address the other problems. 44.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So this rugby, it's just a political calculation?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Life and energy, flood back into Mandela. He sits up agai his seat belt, faces his Chief of Staff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a human calculation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we take away what they cherish -- the Springboks, their national anthem -- we just reinforce the cycle of fear between us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON LINGA, in the front seat. He's not supposed to listen but how could he not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will do what I must to break this cycle. Or it will destroy us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sound of cleats approaching on concrete. Exhausted footsteps. The DRESSING ROOM ATTENDANT PUTS CASES OF BEER (cans) on a side table, rips them open, backs away --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- as the Springboks enter silently, faces miserable, shoulders slumped. They've lost another game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the players grabs a beer, opens it, takes a gigant

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This beer tastes like kuk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- hurls the beer against the wall so hard it ruptures, sending foaming beer everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON PIENAAR as his eyes flash and he shoots to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not the beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pienaar picks up a case of beers, goes to the angry Springbok. 45.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody take a beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is an order. The entire team takes a beer, including Pienaar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A toast ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pienaar cracks his beer, raises it up. They all crack and raise their beers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... to the taste of defeat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That bewilders his team.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drink it. Remember it. And promise yourself never to taste it again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pienaar takes one long swig --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right. It tastes like kuk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- tosses his beer against the wall, so that it ruptures. Eighteen other beers rupture against the wall. The dressi room is awash with beer and foam -- and re-kindled passio

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As with Mandela, Pienaar is a leader, on a smaller scale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both units crammed into the small office. As usual, neith team talks to the other. Jason enters with two files.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's the schedule for the overseas trip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason and the boys look over one, Etienne and his unit lo over the other -- and discuss it amongst themselves in Afrikaans. Hendrick says something pointed, which resonat with the others. 46.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did he just say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He asked when we were supposed to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As well as other basic human functions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey. If Madiba can do it, we can do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela addresses the General Assembly, thanking them for their support in the fight against apartheid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The millions of our people say thank you, and thank you again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Linga and Hendrick are his closest bodyguards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela addresses diplomats, members of Congress, black leaders at a made-for-TV ceremony on the South Lawn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have come here with a message. People of the Unites States of America: Open your markets to us. People of the United States of American: Come and invest in our country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Linga, Jason, Etienne and Hendrick are in on this one -- little island of South Africans in a sea of U.S. SECRET SERVICE PROTECTION.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are in a COURTYARD behind the palace. Drawn by four wh horses, A ROYAL CARRIAGE (an open carriage) pulls up, sto The courtyard quickly fills with liveried footmen, then security guards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: QUEEN ELISABETH and Mandela emerge from the palace. Footm open doors on both sides of the carriage. The Queen and Mandela climb in (the Queen on the right hand side).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When they sit down next to each other, Mandela leans over says something to the Queen that makes her giggle ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... almost. For Queens do not giggle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The carriage pulls forward and these two human icons sit straight, as they get set to face the world.

dialogues.speaker: TV ANNOUNCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ... and in London, President Mandela made quite an impression on the Queen --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON TV: footage of Mandela with the Queen, riding down the mall waving to ecstatic crowds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- as he concluded a gruelling trip

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Pienaar MUTES THE TV, so that he can deliver the late one-liner to Mrs. Pienaar.

dialogues.speaker: MR. PIENAAR
dialogues.text: In related news, it was announced that President Mandela will be visiting South Africa this week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Pienaar laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IN THE BACKGROUND, in the kitchen, a plump, middle-aged Tswana woman washes the dishes and keeps an eye on the TV This is EUNICE, the Pienaar's maid. 48.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She does not find Mr. Pienaar's joke amusing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PRESIDENT'S JET taxis towards the familiar BMW, Merce BMW convoy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela disembarks, very slowly. He is exhausted, his fee are swollen, his knee hurts. This is a very different man than the one we have just seen wooing the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is met at the bottom of the stairs by Hendrick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's good to be home, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela just nods. Too tired to talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hendrick escorts Mandela to the Mercedes, opens the door him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela takes a step towards the open door -- and stagger

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reflexively, Hendrick reaches out, steadies him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela steps out of Hendrick's hands, holds onto the ope door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Travelling the world, begging for money, is very tiring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela reaches into his jacket, pulls a SMALL PACKAGE ou hands it to Hendrick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela slides into the car. Once the door is closed, Hendrick glances at the package. We don't see it. It is t dark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But we do see that Hendrick is amazed by it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hendrick is being driven home through the Highveld night. chews on something really sticky, chewy. He pauses to dislodge some of it from a tooth, before it pulls out a filling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then, he resumes chewing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the bedside table, THE CLOCK clicks from 4:59 to 5:00. Mandela's eyes open in the dark ... close for a second .. then shoot open again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It takes everything Mandela has to sit up and switch on t light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bodyguards' BMW's flank the gate. As the gate opens -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Linga gets out of one BMW, Hendrick gets out of the ot They are alert. It is freezing cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bundled up against the cold, Mandela emerges through the and they close in on him. It is clear that he is pushing himself, physically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see you, father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They keep moving. It is too cold for anything else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How is your family, Hendrick? 50.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Top shape, sir. How about yours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela's smile becomes fixed on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a very big family. 42 million people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then, he stops, turns, heads back towards the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think I want to walk today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hendrick realizes that he blundered, somehow. He shoots a anxious glance at Linga -- who looks at him as if he'd ju committed blasphemy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela goes through the open gate without a word. The ga closes behind him, leaving Linga and Hendrick to watch hi through iron bars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Linga turns on Hendrick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We never ask him about his family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he asks about ours all the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
