dialogues.text: Think about it, man. He's separated from his wife. His children ... how often do you see them here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not a saint, okay. He's a man, with a man's problems -- and he doesn't need us reminding him about them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Linga heads back to his BMW. Hendrick stands at the gate, looking in at the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela shaves, avoiding his own gaze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shaved, showered and dressed, Mandela descends the stairs sits down to breakfast by himself at the big table. He lo at the newspaper headlines, which talk about CRIME RISING THE RAND FALLING, THE MANDELA HONEYMOON OVER etc. etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like any other man, Mandela turns to the SPORTS SECTION f relief -- and finally finds something to smile about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a PICTURE OF PIENAAR. Mandela reacts to it, pleased.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a CABINET MINISTER AND HER ENTOURAGE leave, Barbara enters, holding an envelope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello Barbara. I like that dress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you Madiba.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your pay checks. You haven't been collecting them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela opens the envelope, looks at a check -- and grunt

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is terrible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madiba, it's what De Klerk got. Plus an increase for inflation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, Mandela shakes his head, outraged. 52.

dialogues.speaker: TV ANNOUNCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Today, President Mandela announced that, in his opinion --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on TV throughout) -- his salary is too high.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pienaar and Nerine watch the news with MR. AND MRS PIENAA

dialogues.speaker: MR. PIENAAR
dialogues.text: Dead right. They're all overpaid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IN THE BACKGROUND, once again, Eunice washes the dishes a keeps an eye on the TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has therefore decided to donate a third of his monthly income to charity.

dialogues.speaker: MR. PIENAAR
dialogues.text: Give me the houses and cars they give him and I'll donate a third of my salary too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Francois' cell phone rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Mr. Pienaar) You would not. Not in a million years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hallo, Pienaar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever Pienaar hears on the phone sends him out of the in a hurry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hang on a moment, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: President Mandela said that he wished to set an example to other leaders and cabinet ministers. 53.

dialogues.speaker: MR. PIENAAR
dialogues.text: Fat chance. They're lining their pockets as fast as they can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nerine is interested in the call that sent Pienaar hurryi out of the room. Mr. Pienaar MUTES THE TV.

dialogues.speaker: MR. PIENAAR
dialogues.text: Must be his girlfriend, hey Nerine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He knows I'd bloody kill him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON EUNICE, as eyes and ears alive, she finishes in the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pienaar comes back, stands in the doorway, a stunned expression on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Who was it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pienaar doesn't answer immediately.

dialogues.speaker: MR. PIENAAR
dialogues.text: Told you. It was his girlfriend.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. PIENAAR
dialogues.text: Shush!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been invited to tea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who with?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The President.

dialogues.speaker: MR. PIENAAR
dialogues.text: The President of SA Rugby? Count your fingers after he shakes your hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pienaar points at the muted TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The President.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON THE TV: footage of Mandela with a group of SAUDI PRINC

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eunice turns and looks at Francois, wide-eyed. 54.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Pienaar family all stare at the TV, stunned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wants me over for tea, week after next.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eunice picks up her handbag, puts on her coat and heads f the door, stops when she reaches Pienaar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Francois -- you must tell Madiba that the bus service is very bad, and too expensive. He must please fix it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night everybody.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. PIENAAR
dialogues.text: Good night Eunice, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All eyes on Pienaar.

dialogues.speaker: MR. PIENAAR
dialogues.text: What the hell does he want with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pienaar shakes his head -- he has no idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nerine's modest little car heads towards the seat of powe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nerine drives. Pienaar wears a blue blazer, grey slacks a subdued tie -- and is surprisingly nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Francois, relax. You've met him before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I shook his hand on the rugby field, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't even vote for him. 55.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's still the President.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's had dinner with the Queen. With Presidents and movie stars. All I do is play rugby. What if I pull something stupid in front of him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nerine stops to let Pienaar out. Gives him a kiss, straightens his hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You won't. I'll pick you up right here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pienaar climbs out of Nerine's car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pretty sizeable KNOT OF JOURNALISTS rush towards him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pienaar takes a deep breath. He is a bundle of nerves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Small office packed with big men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See who's coming for tea?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My nephew wants me to get his autograph.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Francois Pienaar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who wants to escort him in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hendrick bolts for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will. 56.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No autographs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know how to do my job, okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hendrick leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's this Pienaar?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't be serious? He's the captain of the Springboks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Linga shrugs, provocatively indifferent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like soccer, myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you know what they say about soccer -- it's gentleman's game played by hooligans. One the other hand, rugby is a hooligan's game played by --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ja, ja, I've heard it before. It wasn't funny the first time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not exactly violin music and roses ... but they are talki to each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hendrick escorts Pienaar back towards Mandela's offices. Hendrick is the bigger man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I ask you a question, Lieutenant?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ja, of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's he like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They pause at the office door. Hendrick ponders that question for a moment, then: 57.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I worked for the previous President, it was my job to be invisible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hendrick opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This President ... he found out I like English toffee and brought me some back, from his visit to the Queen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hendrick ushers Pienaar into Mandela's offices.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To him, nobody is invisible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hendrick gestures to the waiting area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's where you wait. One of his assistants will come for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a bathroom over there, if you need it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hendrick turns to leave, hesitates, turns back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are our chances in the World Cup? I mean, for real.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll do our best. That, I can guarantee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hendrick nods solemnly, heads back to security. Pienaar heads straight for the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hendrick enters. Etienne and the other white bodyguards l up. 58.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, he's not as big as he looks on TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we don't stand a bloody chance in the World Cup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pienaar washes his hands, dries them, dries them again, c his hair, looks at himself in the mirror, adjusts his bla

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pienaar returns to the waiting area, sits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a clock on the wall. One minute to four.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four Japanese trade officials traipse out, having just me Mandela.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The second hand journeys up to vertical. When it hits 4 o'clock exactly --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Mary walks into the waiting area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Pienaar?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pienaar shoots to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This way, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary leads Pienaar back to Mandela's own office, knocks, opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mouth dry, Pienaar nods --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and enters the inner sanctum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela leaps up from behind his desk, crosses the room t meet Pienaar. 59.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Francois, what an honor. I'm so excited.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you for coming all this way to see me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pienaar gulps like a fish out of water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. No problem. Thank you for inviting me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me. How's your ankle?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My ankle?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was told you'd hurt it. Has it healed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pienaar relaxes, visibly. This is small talk he can handl This is Mandela's gift.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The truth is, sir, you never play at a hundred percent, no matter what.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes ... yes. In sports, and in life. Come. Sit. Please. (indicating a chair) Take this one. Looking into the light hurts my eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They sit in the chairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A KNOCK at the door, and MRS. BRITS the old Afrikaner tea lady enters, carrying a laden tea tray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela stands again, immediately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, Mrs. Brits --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pienaar stands just a beat slower. 60.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- you are a shining light in my day.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. BRITS
dialogues.text: Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eyes twinkling, Mrs. Brits puts the tea tray down on the coffee table in front of them. The finest china, cookies a plate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Brits, this is Francois Pienaar. He's the captain of the Springboks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela clearly expects Pienaar to shake hands with Mrs. Brits. Pienaar holds out his hand --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aangename kennis, Mevrou Brits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- gently shakes hers.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. BRITS
dialogues.text: Ek ook, Meneer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shall I pour, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thank you, I think I'd like to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Brits leaves. Mandela does not sit until the door closes behind her. Pienaar only sits after he does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela's manners would not be out of place in Victorian England.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you take your tea, Francois?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milk and sugar, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela pours tea for both of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON PIENAAR, as, just for a moment, he realizes that here is, with the President pouring him a cup of tea. 61.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The English have given us many things, including rugby, but afternoon tea is one of the greatest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela hands Pienaar the tea cup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both men have big hands. Fine china dwarfed and threatene

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the exact moment that both their hands hold the same saucer, Mandela looks Pienaar in the eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have a very difficult job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do? I sell gas braais.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela lets go and Pienaar takes the tea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain of the Springboks. A very difficult job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not compared to yours, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, but then nobody is trying to tear my head off while I'm doing mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pienaar grins. True.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is not so difficult to get people to do their best. And I imagine that anybody who plays for their country does their best, almost automatically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or they wouldn't be chosen in the first place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. But to get people to be better than that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better than they think they can be? Now, that is difficult, I find.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir, it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do we do that? By example? To an extent. But there is more to it than that ... (searching for the right

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... inspiration, perhaps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pienaar is engrossed. This is a master lesson on leadersh from a master.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do we inspire ourselves to greatness, when nothing less will do? How do we inspire everyone around us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes, I think, by using the work of others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Long pause. Pienaar knows to keep quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Robben Island, when things were very hard, I found inspiration in a poem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A poem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Victorian poem. Just words. But they helped me to stand when all I wanted was to lie down --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you didn't come all this way to hear an old man talk about things that make no sense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! They make a lot of sense, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the day of a big match, say a test, in the bus on the way to the stadium, nobody talks. 63.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes ... yes. Everybody is preparing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I think we're ready, I have the bus driver put on a song I've chosen; a theme song. One we all know. We listen together and ... it helps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes! I remember when I was a guest at the 1992 Olympic Games in Barcelona. The whole stadium welcomed me with a song.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the time the future -- our future -- seemed very bleak. But to hear that song, in voices from all over our planet ... it made me very proud to be South African. It helped me to come home and do better. It allowed me to expect more of myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I ask what the song was, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it was Nkosi Sikelel' iAfrika. A very inspiring song.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela looks into Pienaar's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need inspiration, Francois.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brown African eyes, blue African eyes meet over their cup tea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because, in order to build our nation, we all need to exceed our own expectations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something passes between them. Whatever it is has a profo impact on Pienaar. 64.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. We probably do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cameras click and whirr as MANDELA AND PIENAAR SHAKE HAND for the press.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (NOTE that there are NO FLASHES.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pienaar walks away from the President's offices, still processing his meeting with Mandela. He seems a little stunned and mystified. Something profound just happened - but he's not quite sure what.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When Pienaar steps outside and sees all of Pretoria -- al South Africa -- stretching away below him, he pauses. He looks at his country in a new way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A BEEP BEEP from Nerine's car interrupts his reverie, as pulls up at the bottom of the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nerine drives Pienaar away. Pienaar turns, looks back at Union Buildings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hm?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's he like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... he's not like anyone I've ever met before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An unsatisfying answer. Nerine waits for more. But, she isn't going to get it without prying it out of Pienaar. 65.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well? What did he want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the question Pienaar is wrestling with, too. He thinks it over for long enough to drive Nerine crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ag, come on Francois. It's like talking to a bloody brick wall. What did he want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pienaar turns in his seat, looks at her as realization co clear in him ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think he wants us to win the World Cup.

dialogues.speaker: A FRAMED PHOTO OF MANDELA SQUARING OFF AGAINST MUHAMMAD A
dialogues.text: looks down --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- on Mandela, who is surrounded by HIS GRANDCHILDREN IN LIVING ROOM. Mandela likes the babies. THEIR PARENTS, sho and shepherd the kids, keeping them on their best behavio

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- for the PHOTOGRAPHERS shooting this family gathering. Seeing the photographers makes this feel staged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela looks past the photographers, sees his daughter ZINDZI glancing in from the doorway, and then moving on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela disentangles the babies, stands, leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the DINING ROOM, Zindzi looks down at a BIG FRONT PAGE PHOTO OF MANDELA AND PIENAAR SHAKING HANDS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is a modern, cosmopolitan young woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When Mandela enters, Zindzi looks up from the newspaper w a very Mandela-like grunt. 66.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't matter what I think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, it does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. I think he looks like one of the policemen who forced us out of our house when you were in jail. I don't like seeing you shake his hand. And I'm not the only one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela overreacts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You criticize without understanding. You seek only to address your own feelings. This is selfish thinking. It does not serve the nation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zindzi shakes her head, turns, leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait. Please. I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela wants to apologize, doesn't know how. Instead, he pulls AN ENVELOPE out of his pocket, holds it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you give this to your mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bracelet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zindzi looks into the envelope. In it is the BEADED BRACELET, from earlier, from the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just throw it away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have the right to. It's not mine. 67.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If she left it here, she meant to throw it away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only children know how to twist the dagger so deftly. Mandela turns away so that his daughter cannot see his ey

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man so at ease with strangers does not know how to talk his own family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SAME NEWSPAPER PHOTO of Mandela and Pienaar that Zind was looking at -- only, this time, someone is cutting it very carefully. Eunice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Pienaar enters to get something from the fridge, sees what Eunice is doing. Eunice stops cutting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Pienaar looks down at the photo for a long moment. He doesn't know how to react to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Pienaar said you were finished with the paper.

dialogues.speaker: MR. PIENAAR
dialogues.text: Ja. Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Pienaar leaves. Eunice keeps cutting until the photo be lifted up. She nods, proud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On a PRACTISE FIELD at this world-class facility, the SPRINGBOK SQUAD (about 30 guys) sprint to the 25 m line, drops, begins 20 explosive push-ups.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NOTE, also, that at least half of the players who faced t British Lions earlier are gone.) 68.

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER OF SPORT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The World Cup is played every four years. Sixteen teams qualify from around the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE MINISTER OF SPORTS BRIEFS MANDELA on the World Cup, w the help of a BIG DIAGRAM ON AN EASEL (just like a March Madness bracket layout, showing all the teams.) The Minis looks ragged, exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER OF SPORT
dialogues.text: Four pools of four teams each, playing in nine different venues around the country. Two teams will advance from each pool to the quarter finals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela studies the diagram. He loves this stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Ivory Coast qualified. This is wonderful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (For the record, the sixteen teams who qualified were: So Africa, New Zealand, Australia, England, Scotland, Irelan Wales, Canada, Romania, Italy, France, Japan, West Samoa, Argentina, Tonga and Ivory Coast.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Springbok squad leap up after the push-ups, sprint to 50 m line, drop, begin 20 rapid crunches --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- under the critical eye of the new COACH and MANAGER.

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER OF SPORT
dialogues.text: Australia won the previous World Cup. New Zealand won the one before that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MINISTER OF SPORT (cont'd) They're both clear favorites to reach the finals this time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: According to the experts, we'll reach the quarter finals, and no further.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: According to the experts, you and I are still supposed to be in jail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That brings a grin from the Minister of Sport.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The coach blows his whistle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON PIENAAR, as he leaps to his feet, leads the charge bac the 25 m line.

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER OF SPORT
dialogues.text: You make a personal appearance at the finals, and at the opening match between the Springboks and Australia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The finals will be broadcast to over a billion people around the world, live.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A billion people watching us! (wheels turning in his

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes ... yes. This is a great opportunity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hands on their knees, sucking air, retching, the squad ha worked their way down the full length of the field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I reckon you've knocked the stuffing out of them today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't even begun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We may not be the most talented team in the world -- but we're going to be the fittest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He blows his whistle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And back! The squad can't believe their ears. No one moves. Except Pienaar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on boys, let's show him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Staggering more than sprinting, Pienaar heads towards the line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit, what's Pienaar been eating?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, they follow him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alone in his office, Mandela looks at the World Cup diagr for a moment, then picks up his phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please call the head of South African rugby for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thirty completely wiped-out athletes. Some are too tired shower, some have made it that far, but are too tired to change.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pienaar has showered and changed and slumps next to his locker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SPRINGBOK MANAGER enters, followed by the RUGBY PRESIDENT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pienaar and the boys drag themselves upright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Rugby President looks them over as if they were his v own stable of race horses -- a stable he's not entirely s he likes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Afternoon men. It's good to see you working so hard. I have a short announcement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As part of the PR buildup to the World Cup, you will be conducting coaching clinics in townships all over the country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The players greet this announcement with complete silence

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you have plenty on your plates already -- but this is a request that comes from the top. (looking at Pienaar,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The very top.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Rugby President turns on his heel, and leaves, follow by the Manager.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The players say nothing for a long moment, but body langu alone shows that they are completely disgusted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is complete crap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are we some kind of circus act now? 72.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't have time for kuk like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys are getting angrier by the second.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They expect us to play our best, to give our bloody all, then they add to our bloody workload ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lock turns to Chester.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think about this, Chester?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All eyes on Chester, as if the poor guy is a magic guide world they barely understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I try not to think. It interferes with my rugby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The perfect answer for these guys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See! Now there's a rugby player. Talk to them Francois.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make them see that this is a waste of time we don't have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All eyes on their Captain -- who shakes his head, no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not going to talk to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whether we like it or not, we're more than just a rugby team. We're ... we're ambassadors inside our own country. And we might as well get used to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. Rebellious silence. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this you speaking, or Mandela? 73.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pienaar's eyes are fierce. He needs them to see how serio he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know me better than that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Times change. We need to change, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is clear that much of his team disagrees with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE-UP ON A TV -- horrible, startling images of the OKLAHOMA CITY BOMBING.

dialogues.speaker: TV ANNOUNCER, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: We're looking at the remains of the Federal Building in Oklahoma City, America, which was destroyed today in a massive explosion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PULL BACK to reveal that we are in Mandela's offices. Barbara, Mary, other assistants look on. So do the bodyguards. All faces stunned, appalled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela approaches slowly from his office, drawn in by th horrible, irresistible images. He stands behind his peopl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one has claimed responsibility yet, but authorities say that the timing and target mark this as the work of white, right-wing fanatics. An act of revenge for the FBI killings in Waco, Texas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason and Linga share a pointed look. South Africa is a global leader in white, right-wing fanatics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The explosive, a truck bomb, was apparently a simple mixture of commonly available industrial and agricultural materials.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all we need.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A homemade explosive from materials every boer already has.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then, Jason realizes that Mandela is standing right next him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So far, the official death toll stands at over a 100 people, which includes at least 12 children from a day care center in the Federal building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela turns to Barbara.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please call President Clinton for me. I wish to offer him our condolences.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela turns to Jason, eyes deep and dark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you see why forgiveness is essential, Jason?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Revenge only begets revenge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Mandela walks back to his office, there is a look of u sorrow on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A luxury bus heads along the freeway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Springbok squad rides in style. Most are wearing tracksuits, most are asleep. Pienaar is awake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same township where Sipho rejected the Springbok rugb jersey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At one edge we find what passes for a SOCCER FIELD. Just littered rectangular expanse of Highveld winter dirt. 75.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TV VANS and a very nervous SPRINGBOK MANAGEMENT CREW driv the edge of the field, stop, get out --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and are immediately mobbed by THREADBARE, EXCITED KIDS many of them begging for cash and candy. SIPHO in the thi of things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the Springbok management crew pulls a ROLLED BANNE two spiked poles out of their van.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mallet and banner in hand, the management crew head to th edge of the field, mobbed by shouting, whistling township kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They hammer one pole into the ground, unroll the banner ( from the back so that we can't read the words), get set t hammer the second pole into the ground --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- except that there is a SMASHED BEER BOTTLE in the way. Broken glass everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look at the broken glass, then turn and look across field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Broken glass glints in the low sun, all over the field.

dialogues.speaker: SPRINGBOK MANAGEMENT CREW
dialogues.text: They can't play on this.

dialogues.speaker: SPRINGBOK MANAGEMENT CREW
dialogues.text: When are they due?

dialogues.speaker: SPRINGBOK MANAGEMENT CREW
dialogues.text: Fifteen minutes.

dialogues.speaker: SPRINGBOK MANAGEMENT CREW
dialogues.text: Plenty of time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reaches into his wallet, pulls out a R100 note (about $17), holds it up high. The kids yell for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mayhem, as kids sprint out across the field, hunting for glass. Sipho goes for the tiniest, most treacherous shard

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus hits a rut in the dirt road with an almighty jolt which wakes the sleeping Springboks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look out of the windows and see the absolutely helli outskirts of the township. Every possible incarnation of poverty, as far as the eye can see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This shocks them. Most of them have never been anywhere l this township.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit, I'm glad I don't live here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The driver sounds the horn, as they pull into the townshi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus pulls up at the field --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- which is covered with kids on their hands and knees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell are they doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The driver sounds the horn again, and the kids on the fie sprint for the bus, hands and pockets full of broken glas

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't forget, we've got TV cameras on us at all times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a bloody joke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the kids approach the bus, they dump their broken glas under the banner, which reads -- 77.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- brown, green, white, blue shards tinkling and piling u like lethal jewels, backlit in the low winter sun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the big kids gets the R100. Attention focussed on

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- until the bus door opens with a loud hiss of hydraulic and the Springboks exit, one by one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pienaar first, with a huge NET BAG OF PRACTISE BALLS over shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Springboks are all so big, so strong, so healthy, the look like gods, or aliens, emerging from a spaceship. The kids go quiet, awed and uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Until Chester Williams steps off the bus, and there is a collective sigh of recognition and wonder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, the kids can relate to the Springboks. Even Sipho, w looks on from the side of the field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Springbok management notes it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The TV crews note it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pienaar notes it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay Chester -- I reckon you're up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What am I supposed to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you do best.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pienaar turns to the throng.

dialogues.speaker: WHO WANTS TO PLAY RUGBY
dialogues.text: A roar. They all do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pienaar opens the net bag full of rugby balls, gives a ba to Chester.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let rip. 78.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chester boots the ball out over the crowd, high and incredibly far in the thin winter air. (60 yards, easily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pienaar tosses balls to the others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's do our best.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One after another, the Springboks kick the balls high int the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go get them!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kids go after them. Sipho stays on the sideline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barely controlled chaos. Each Springbok works with one ba and a group of kids. There are THREE THEMES to this monta

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FIRST, a primer on the basic rules of rugby, with demonstrations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who here knows the first rule of rugby?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only hit the other players when the ref isn't looking!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laughter. A good ice-breaker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. The first rule of rugby is you can only pass the ball backwards or sideways.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pienaar demonstrates. (NOTE: All the rules are demonstrated.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - If you drop the ball, or pass it forwards, you scrum for possession. - This is a scrum. - You kick forwards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VARIOUS SPRINGBOKS (cont'd) If you kick it out of bounds, you throw it back in to a lineout. - This is a lineout. - You score in four ways: a try, when you dot the ball down behind the try line. That's five points. - Another two points when you convert the try by kicking the ball through the uprights. - Three points for a penalty kick. - Three points for a drop kick. - Have you got all that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agh, bugger it, let's just run and pass. Whoever drops the ball does pushups!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SECOND, as the players work with the kids, they get into Much to their own surprise, they enjoy the energy, they e the kids, they enjoy the giving. Even the grumpiest, most conservative Springbok.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Who wants to scrum against me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One huge man scrums against a horde of kids. He pushes th backwards with a roar -- then lets them push him backward They love it, the cameras love it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE THIRD THEME shows the emergence of Chester Williams a the face of the Springboks. The crowd of kids around him twice as big as any other player's crew. Given Chester's basically shy nature, he finds it all a bit overwhelming. The TV cameras follow him even more closely than they fol Pienaar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AT ONE POINT, an errant pass puts a rugby ball right at Sipho's feet. He hesitates, then picks it up. He doesn't just hold it, he feels it. END THE MONTAGE as the luxury bus pulls away, surrounded horde of cheering kids, many of whom hold new rugby balls under their arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One blast on the horn, one answering cheer from the kids the bus slowly accelerates away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cabinet meeting in the rainbow nation, with Mandela at head of the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The MINISTER OF THE ENVIRONMENT is making a presentation about a campaign to put an end to littering by plastic ba Behind him is a VERY DRAMATIC SLIDE IMAGE of a rural barb wire fence festooned with wind-blown plastic bags.

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER OF THE ENVIRONMENT
dialogues.text: -- and in addition to the nationwide PR campaign, we propose that all retail outlets charge a nominal fee for plastic bags --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary enters quietly, slips a piece of paper in front of Mandela, who reads it, holds up his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Minister, please forgive me. This sounds excellent, and we will return to it, but if you'll indulge me for just one minute --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela nods to Mary, who switches on a big TV on the wal which shows NEWS FOOTAGE OF THE COACHING CLINIC in the township.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When we see the FOOTAGE OF THE LOCK SCRUMMING WITH THE KI Mandela laughs, delighted, turns to his cabinet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see, that picture is worth any number of speeches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. and Mrs. Pienaar watch the same report ON TV. Mr. Pienaar has quite a different reaction to Mandela's.

dialogues.speaker: MR. PIENAAR
dialogues.text: Tell me something -- how does this help them win rugby matches?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ESTABLISHING SHOT from the air of Cape Town, one of the m beautiful cities in the world. We see the Cape Peninsula, the harbor, the city itself draped around the shoulders o Table Mountain like a multi-colored Mediterranean shawl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On its descent towards Cape Town airport, a SOUTH AFRICAN AIRWAYS JET flies across the view with the smiling face o Chester Williams painted on the fuselage.

dialogues.speaker: BOLAND BOTHA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: This is Boland Botha coming to you live from Cape Town airport --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From a position near an IDLING LUXURY BUS, Boland speaks his mike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- where the Springbok flight has just landed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON THE APRON, the team disembarks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys are dressed in Springbok blazers, slacks and tie A magnificent sight. Gladiators in top shape, faces appropriately stern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People -- white people -- clap and cheer as the team ente the building.

dialogues.speaker: BOLAND BOTHA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The green and gold have one week to put the finishing touches to their gruelling training program --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The team feeds on the energy. They walk taller, faster, closer together.

dialogues.speaker: BOLAND BOTHA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: -- and I, for one, have to admit to being cautiously excited. 82.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON BOLAND BOTHA, next to the bus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I say cautiously, because in my humble opinion --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behind Boland, the Springboks get into the bus, fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- this team has been over-trained on the field, and over-committed off it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beautiful Cape Dutch style mansion. Mandela stands in h HOME OFFICE, watches Boland on TV. The MINISTER OF SPORTS with him.

dialogues.speaker: BOLAND BOTHA, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: Which makes beating a powerhouse Australian side in the Cup opener next week a tall order, especially since this is an inexperienced team with a history of coming up short in big matches. This is Boland

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela switches off the TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Around the world -- objectively -- what are they saying about our chances against Australia?

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER OF SPORT
dialogues.text: Everyone thinks they'll beat us. And if they do, we'll have to go through England and the All Blacks just to get to the Final.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So it is very important that we beat Australia. (to Minister of Sport) Thank you. 83.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Minister leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alone in his office, Mandela sits, thinks, gets a sheet o paper with his PERSONAL LETTERHEAD on it, uncaps his foun pen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OVER MANDELA'S SHOULDER, we see him write, and then underline, the title INVICTUS by W.E. Henley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BARBARA KNOCKS, pokes her head in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Cabinet Ministers are here to brief you on the trip to Taiwan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be right out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From memory, Mandela writes the first line of the poem:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out of the night that covers me ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The luxury bus comes around a bend in a leafy suburb of C Town, right under the flanks of Table Mountain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahead, we see NEWLANDS STADIUM, home of the World Cup ope between the Springboks and Australia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A magnificent old stadium in a beautiful setting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All eyes on the stadium as the bus idles past, very slowl This is a coach move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One week, boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excited faces become grave, serious. The bus goes quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coach nods to himself, pleased.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus pulls away. 84.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WE STAY AT NEWLANDS STADIUM -- and SWOOP UPWARDS until we looking down on the stadium and surrounding streets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This AERIAL SHOT BECOMES A BIG MAP --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- pinned to a board in the security center.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need snipers on top of the stadium and these surrounding buildings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason leads the meeting. He uses an old-fashioned pointer All of Mandela's security detail present, plus LOCAL COP BRASS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We want these two approaches completely sanitized.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two approaches?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not going to decide which way we bring him in until the very last moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need uniforms, plain clothes, sharp-shooters ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And sniffer dogs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. No truck bombs, no Oklahoma City.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The locals stir, share a look. This is going to be a nightmare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've got an army unit on standby at Silvermine, if you need more men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not an option the cops favor, judging by their faces. 85.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not taking any chances, okay. The President's going to be very exposed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Much too exposed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The silver Mercedes tools into Cape Town past Groote Schu Mandela travels with Barbara, who opens her first file of journey -- but is forestalled by her boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara, I have been studying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the summit in Taiwan? Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Not exactly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela hands Barbara a folded SPORTS SECTION.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Test me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara unfolds the sports section --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- to reveal COLOR PHOTOGRAPHS OF THE SPRINGBOK SQUAD. A collector's pull-out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara looks at the photos, shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look like thugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela just smiles at that remark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Block out the names. See if I can recognize them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara gives her boss a put-upon look -- this is such a waste of time! -- but blocks out the first row of names. Mandela points at the first photo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andre Joubert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gavin Johnson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did I get them right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Madiba.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (immensely pleased with

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is how I used to study in law school. (next photo is of Chester) Unfortunately, Chester is far too easy to identify. But that will change. It must.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The entire Springbok squad has been on a training run thr Cape Town, on ordinary streets, through ordinary people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (This is unthinkable in top-level sports anywhere else. I really happened.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When they are recognized, drivers toot their horns, pedestrians cheer, kids on bicycles ride with them (mostl still white).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they approach the hotel grounds, Pienaar surges to the front, so that he can give them a message as they pass through the hotel gate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Players-only meeting in the team room after dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Normally a conference room, now equipped with fridge, poo table, ping pong, sofas, TV etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The entire team has assembled, minus Pienaar. A quiet air Serious, relaxed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pienaar enters, holding a sheaf of XEROXED PAGES, begins hand them out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this? Homework? 87.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sort of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The players look down at the pages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON A PAGE: the words to Nkosi Sikelel' iAfrika, in Xhosa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One by one, the players look from the page to Pienaar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cappie? What's this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need to learn it. We can't just mouth the words anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody cares, as long as we win matches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They do care.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's their song, not ours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a terrorist song.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They used to arrest you for singing it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now it's one of our anthems.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he's talking to a deeply conservative group of guys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cap. You know I leave my guts on the field for you, and you know I'd follow you into a fight anywhere, any time. But this ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hooker crumples the page, is about to throw it away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... I can't even read it. I definitely can't pronounce the words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One look at his men, and Pienaar knows he has hit a wall. 88.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, boys. It's optional. Take it if you want to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The players are relieved. Pienaar looks down at the sheet paper for a moment, then looks up at the guys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It means "God Bless Africa".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which you have to admit, we could use.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nonetheless, most of the players crumple the pages, toss into the closest trash can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell us, Mr. President, have you always been a rugby fan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela appears with Boland Botha on his show, under a ON TEAM, ONE NATION banner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People do not realize that I once played rugby myself, when I was a student at Fort Hare. It is a very rough game. Almost as rough as politics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boland laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHOTS OF BOOZE BEING DELIVERED to people's houses all ove the country by BOTTLE STORE DELIVERY VANS (a very South African alcoholic enabling service). Lots and lots of boo

dialogues.speaker: BOLAND BOTHA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: How do you think the Springboks will do?

dialogues.speaker: MANDELA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I think they will do very well. Their level of commitment is tremendous. 89.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE SPRINGBOKS TRAIN on an isolated field at the SILVERMI ARMY BASE outside Cape Town. Tactics and refinements, not fitness training.

dialogues.speaker: BOLAND BOTHA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Now, it's been said that you used to support any team who played against the Springboks.

dialogues.speaker: MANDELA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Obviously, that is no longer true. I am one hundred percent behind our boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JASON, ETIENNE, LINGA and HENDRICK stand anxiously outsid Newlands Stadium. One of them points to the top of a tall building nearby -- a Eureka! moment, for reasons we don't understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After all, if I cannot change when circumstances demand it, how can I ask others to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SOUTH AFRICAN DEFENSE FORCE HELICOPTER hovers over the building next to Newlands stadium.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IN THE HELICOPTER, Mandela, Jason, Linga, all wearing rad headsets. All wearing suits, as if for a state occasion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going to land you on top of that building. We'll own the road between it and the stadium.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela likes it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason gives the pilot a nod and they take off down the peninsula towards Silvermine Army base.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FROM THE HELICOPTER, MANDELA LOOKS down at his country, a finds it good. 90.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helicopter against spectacular scenery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela points down. Jason and Linga look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: POV FROM THE AIR: They can see the Springboks practising right below them, on the army base.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela pulls out the SPORTS SECTION with the Springbok t on it. His study guide. He takes a last minute glance at as the helicopter loses altitude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela's helicopter lands at the edge of the field, and brings practise to a halt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON COACH -- not happy, but what's he going to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela springs out of the helicopter, energized, excited Linga and Jason with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The players assemble in a loose, semi-formal unit. Not a line, but orderly. (We may or may not notice that Chester Williams is missing.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pienaar stands at the front, relaxed. He's an old hand wi Mandela, by now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Francois, gentlemen -- forgive me for interrupting your work the day before such an important match ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... I just wanted to wish you good luck, in person.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a naughty twinkle in Mandela's eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And sometimes, very seldom, as President, I am allowed to do what I want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all laugh. 91.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela wades in amongst them, leaving Linga and Jason behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Picture this: Behind the barbed wire security of a modern South African military base, a tall, regal black man in h 70's is surrounded by huge, sweating, battered, brutal- looking white men --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. President, this is --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know who this is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good luck, Andre. (shaking hands with all of

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good luck Brendan, we're behind you all. Japie -- etc

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- every single one of whose names he has committed to memory. Statesmanship is often about attention to detail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The players are awe-struck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (FOR THE RECORD: Andre, Gavin, James, Japie, Christiaan, Brendan, Hennie, Joel, Johan, Joost, Marius, James, Chris Pieter, Garry, Mark, Kobus, Hannes, Krynauw, Ruben, Franc Robby, Adriaan, Rudolf.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT AWAY to Jason and Linga, who are amazed by what they' seeing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you ever imagine this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How could I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the time Mandela has shaken every single player's hand has won the team over, coach and manager included. They glow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then, Mandela frowns, steps back, looks at all of the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But where is Chester?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pienaar doesn't answer immediately, he looks at his coach first. Coach nods. 92.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's injured, sir. His hamstring. We're trying to keep it quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he out for the whole tournament?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With hamstrings, who knows?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll miss him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The whole country will miss him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A somewhat sour note to leave on. But it's about to be rescued.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. President, sir --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Hennie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- this is for you. From us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The huge, thick man holds out a GREEN CAP with gold pipin and a Springbok leaping above the visor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela takes the cap as if he has just been given a holy relic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am honored. Truly honored.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela runs his finger over the embroidered Springbok leaping across the front of the cap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good luck gentlemen. Your country supports you, completely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The team applauds, beaming, glowing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela turns to go back to the helicopter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Francois, walk with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pienaar walks Mandela back towards the helicopter. 93.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have something for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela reaches into his jacket, pulls out an ENVELOPE WI THE PRESIDENT'S LETTERHEAD on it. Gives it to Pienaar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This helped me, many times. Perhaps it will help you, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pienaar holds the envelope, stares upwards at the rising, departing helicopter, as do the rest of the team -- until Coach blows his whistle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enough fun and games! We've still got work to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason paces restlessly, going over his mental check list, making sure he hasn't missed anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela reads, scrawls comments, signs papers from a big pile. Mary enters with his glass of milk and his pills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's time for bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I'll stay up a little longer. The country is excited tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You need to sleep. The doctor said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doctor has no sense of occasion. 94.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela turns on the TV, begins flipping channels. Rugby, rugby, rugby. Mandela is sucked in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The coach and the manager. Cats on a hot tin roof.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's nothing more we can do. The game plan's good. It's just a matter of the boys executing it tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's Pienaar's job. It's in his hands, now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Room dark but for one small desk light. Pienaar stands at the window, looking out across Cape Town. He is deep in thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pienaar turns away from the window, goes to the desk, whe under one small light, we see "Invictus", the poem Mandel wrote out by hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pienaar begins reading it. There is a soft knock at his door. Pienaar goes to it, opens it. It is Nerine, accompanied by a cop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pienaar nods at the cop, steps back so that Nerine can en As soon as the door closes behind her, Nerine says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know the best thing about you being the captain?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh ... the honor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have to share a room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nerine gives Pienaar a scorching kiss. He resists ... the responds -- then pulls away. 95.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Francois, come on. It's been weeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh uh. I need to be angry for tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nerine takes a deep breath, nods, turns away -- and sees poem on Mandela's personal letterhead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A poem. From the President.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How does a poem help you play rugby?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same way your visit does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inspiration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A massive crowd roars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Wallaby flyhalf runs forward, puts his boot into the ball, sends it soaring towards the waiting Springboks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Springbok lock rises high into the air, supported on sides, takes the ball out of the air perfectly --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- just as the Wallaby pack closes in and huge men meet w an adrenaline-fueled crunch of bodies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The World Cup has begun at last.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But not for Chester Williams. Clad in Springbok blazer an tie, he sits behind the coach, the manager and the reserv in the stands -- and almost succeeds in hiding his utter disappointment at not being on the field. 96.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela looks on, calmly. The Minister of Sport isn't lat for this match. The President of Rugby is pale with nerve

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behind Mandela, stand Linga and Hendrick. The VIP box is safe place, but Jason isn't taking any chances.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason prowls through the stadium, talking constantly on h radio. Hunter's adrenaline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back to action on the field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The highlights we see here should match the rugby primer saw in the township. This continues the education of thos who do not know rugby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, for instance, we see a ball knocked forward, and the resulting scrum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see a ball kicked out of bounds, and the resulting lineout.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see scintillating passing, rucking, mauling, tackling, strategic kicking at it's very best. Both teams are crisp and strong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- with SHOTS OF THE SECURITY ARRANGEMENTS (snipers, lots lots of uniformed cops inside and out, sniffer dogs etc. overseen by Jason) --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- with SHOTS OF THE CROWD, which, unlike the earlier tes against the Lions, is completely and passionately united behind the Springboks (all commentators talk about the extraordinary passion of the crowd, that day) --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- always returning to the VIP BOX, where something interesting is taking place right behind Mandela: Linga Moonsamy, the rugby scorner, the soccer lover, loses his scowling reserve and gets sucked into the game. 97.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When a ball soars between the uprights and everyone in th box groans, Linga leans towards Hendrick and asks:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They scored.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When another ball soars between the uprights and the crow roars, Linga asks again:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We scored.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A third ball through the uprights. Before Linga can ask:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They scored again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fourth ball, to the joy of the others in the box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We scored?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ja. We're tied.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fifth ball through the uprights, and the crowd goes wil

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're up by three.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ACTION ON THE FIELD, as a Wallaby drive combining backs a forwards moves relentlessly towards the Springbok try lin Six times the drive is stopped by Springbok tackling, but Wallabies keep possession and, on the seventh wave of the assault score a beautiful open try, which is converted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A ripple of concern goes through the crowd --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and the VIP box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're ahead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By four.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nerves in the box. 98.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But not on the field, as Pienaar starts a drive with a ta we feel ourselves, resulting in a change of possession --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and a stunning, open field try scored in the corner by Springbok wing, who raises his fist in the air, after juk the last Wallaby to try and tackle him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd roars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the VIP box, Mandela is on his feet, shaking hands wit everyone he can reach, including Linga and Hendrick, and waiter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The difficult, angled conversion is missed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're only ahead by one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another penalty kick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're ahead by four.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A drop goal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By seven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An incredible try by the Springbok fly half.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By fourteen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone dares to dream. The classic South African pencha for pessimism begins to abate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two things to note: The crowd roar grows and grows and gr and is echoed in the VIP box. Even Jason turns to look at the action on the field -- but only for a second. Also, t match serves as the coming-out party for the SPRINGBOK FL HALF, who scores 22 of South Africa's 27 points this day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUDDENLY, A REFEREE'S WHISTLE CREATES PANDEMONIUM on the field, in the stands, and in the VIP box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We won! 99.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We did?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela shoots to his feet, pushes his chair away and beg the famous "Mandela shuffle" -- a very cool African boogi that is one of his signature moves. ON THE MANDELA SHUFFL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- the same shuffle hours later, at a VIP party. Mandela changed clothes, wears one of his Indonesian-inspired "Ma shirts" and dances energetically with the absolutely stun TROPHY WIFE of one of the VIP's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must be very pleased!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What man would not be pleased to be dancing with a beautiful woman like you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Mr. President, you're exaggerating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indeed not. My father was a Xhosa chief, and therefore a polygamist. As you know, I am not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But when I look at you ... I envy my father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man is a major flirt, and really enjoying himself. Bu once again, he is dancing with a stranger --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and, when we get close to his eyes, we realize that Mandela is pushing himself way past empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason is asleep on his face, in his suit and shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big party, spilling onto the streets. Most of the partier are white. Black South Africans look on, or serve drinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We follow the crowd into a big sports bar --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- where the Springboks are pounding beers and blowing of the steam of months of training grind, plus a huge win.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even though most of the players are with their wives or girlfriends, pretty, single women crowd them, two and thr deep, men pay for round after round of beers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pienaar and Nerine are part of the action. Then Pienaar g a TEXT MESSAGE which makes him shake his head, give Nerin chagrined look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He grabs the Springbok closest to him, puts his mouth nea the player's ear and screams again the hubbub:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Springbok shakes his head -- bloody coach -- grabs th player next to him, repeats it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pienaar watches the message travelling through his team - and grins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then, something catches his eye on one of the big overhea TV's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON THE TV: news footage of the Mandela victory boogie. Th boogie is followed by a quick "How far we have come" type montage. One of the images shows an island ringed by roug surf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pienaar gets an idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pienaar leads his hung-over, sleep-deprived team on a ver slow jog through the mostly empty streets. 101.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When he gets to an intersection, he sneaks a peek down at palm of his left hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE-UP ON PIENAAR'S HAND, where he has drawn a crude st map.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pienaar takes a left at the intersection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another intersection, another peek at the map on his hand and another left turn, takes the team --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- back onto the waterfront, to an idling FERRY BOAT, whe the coach and the manager wait for them -- along with the player's wives and girlfriends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope you're not that slow next week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pienaar grins, stops. The team stops around him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A change of pace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ferry pulls away from the waterfront, with the team o board, pulling on tracksuits against the cold sea air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is early winter. The seas are fairly rough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So are the stomachs of the `boks who partied hard last ni

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's bloody idea was this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON PIENAAR, innocent as a lamb. 102.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behind the ferry, Cape Town and Table Mountain, in all th glory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahead of the ferry, one of the most notorious island pris in modern history --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robben Island lies only eight miles from the mainland. It two miles long, with sandy beaches full of penguins and seals. It would be pretty --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- but for its MAXIMUM SECURITY PRISON. Concrete, barbed wire, guard towers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (In 1995, the political prisoner wing was shut, but the island still housed criminal prisoners, so the island sti had the feel of real incarceration. Today, it is a touris destination.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they approach the island, a sense of dark history sett over the Springboks and their partners.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the Springboks turns to a DECKHAND, getting ready moor at the jetty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do they bring the prisoners here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On this boat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sobering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Springboks and their partners step onto dry land with some relief, look around at the prison, humbled. 103.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Imagine being able to see Cape Town so close by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That would make it worse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
