dialogues.text: They head towards the prison entrance, slowly becoming a tighter and tighter bunch. The ghosts of Mandela, and all the others who spent much of their lives here, are very strong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VARIOUS SHOTS OF THE SPRINGBOK PARTY, in the EXERCISE YAR the LIME QUARRY, the MESS HALL. None of the usual horsing around. This place affects them, deeply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Section B is the bleak political wing. Tiny cells line ea side of a damp concrete hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A PRISON GUARD shows the Springboks into the hallway, and they dwarf it, as they stand there, shocked. Shocked at w was done in their names. This group is as quiet as we hav ever seen them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can we see the President's cell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, of course. (leading them down past

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've done it up just the way it was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They reach a cell with a piece of white cardboard on the door, showing the number 466/64 -- MANDELA'S PRISON NUMBE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing at the number) That means he was the 466th prisoner admitted in 1964.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Prison Guard unlocks the door, pulls it open, then unlocks the metal grill that is the inside door. 104.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pienaar peers into the cell. It is tiny. There is no bed, just a sisal mat on the concrete floor, with a couple of blankets. A chamber pot, a short bench, a tin cup and pla are the only other objects in the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A couple of small lockers are screwed high to the wall. T barred window is opaque. It lets in light but does not al the prisoner a view.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When Pienaar enters, we see how small the cell really is. can reach out and touch the opposite walls at the same ti

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a bleak, horrible, dehumanizing place. Pienaar is stunned by it. He turns, slowly, looking at Mandela's wor for over twenty years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other Springboks and their partners wait to look into cell themselves, a little puzzled by how much time Pienaa taking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pienaar almost looks as if he is in a trance. He hears Mandela's voice in the cell with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out of the night that covers me, Black as the pit from pole to pole, I thank whatever gods may be For my unconquerable soul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, Pienaar sees Mandela in prison clothes, in the cell. (The image is unclear, ghostly.)

dialogues.speaker: MANDELA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: In the fell clutch of circumstance I have not winced nor cried aloud. Under the bludgeonings of chance My head is bloody, but unbow'd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pienaar sees Mandela sitting on the dirt in the prison ya breaking up rock with a hammer, along with rows of other political prisoners. 105.

dialogues.speaker: MANDELA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Beyond this place of wrath and tears Looms but the Horror of the shade, And yet the menace of the years Finds and shall find me unafraid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pienaar sees Mandela leading his fellow prisoners to the quarry, to mine lime under the eye of a guard who looks l Pienaar.

dialogues.speaker: MANDELA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It matters not how strait the gate, How charged with punishment the scroll, I am the master of my fate: I am the captain of my soul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gates open. Linga gets out of one BMW, Hendrick out o the other. We know the routine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only, Mandela doesn't appear for his walk. Linga and Hendrick wait for a moment, then head in through the gate

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- break into a sprint, when they see MANDELA'S FORM, CRUMPLED on the lawn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara, Mary, the house staff, plus Linga, Hendrick, Eti and Jason, all wait. All are scared. Nobody talks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SOUND OF FOOTSTEPS from on the top floor brings them their feet. MANDELA'S DOCTOR descends the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's simple exhaustion, but it'll lead to worse if it's not treated. He needs complete rest. And I don't mean just shifting the affairs of state to his bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No phone calls, no visitors, no meetings. No politics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know him. He won't do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I'm going to put him into hospital. In isolation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Not yet. I'll threaten him with hospital if he doesn't behave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll cancel everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I'll come back tonight to make sure he's not working.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doctor leaves. The rest of them look at each other, relieved ... and maybe a little guilty, for letting thing get this bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Mary, aside) Don't cancel the trip to Taiwan. Not yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dark. Curtains drawn. The door opens quietly. A shaft of light from the door shows Mandela, on his back in bed, ey closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara enters. The sight of Mandela lying like this is chilling. It is too close to what he would look like lyin in a casket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara makes sure he is breathing. He is. She unplugs hi phone, takes it. Unplugs his TV. Sweeps the room for papers, articles, legal briefs. For the first time, she takes an arm load of stuff away from him. She gives Mande one last, long look, closes the door behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We stay behind and look at Mandela, and ponder South Afri fate if this were worse than just deep, sedated sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chester Williams jogs under the tense eye of coach, train manager and Pienaar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He accelerates, running fast, but not sprinting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not good enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chester opens it up. Full sprint, sustained. Pienaar grin Chester is back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's hope the Samoans don't injure it again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ONE, BRIEF SHOT of a typically brutal Samoan tackle, and ensuing foul play in the maul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FOUR QUICK SHOTS of Chester williams scoring four tries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ONE MORE SHOT of the Springboks trudging off the field. Every single player is bruised or bleeding, or both.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking frail, but better than before, Mandela pencils in score ON THE WORLD CUP BRACKET DIAGRAM: SOUTH AFRICA 42, WESTERN SAMOA 14. The diagram shows us that this was a quarter final match.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can see that he has entered all the South African scor

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (For the record: South Africa 27 - Australia 18; South Af 21 - Romania 3; South Africa 20 - Canada 0.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the semi-finals, against South Africa, Mandela pencil France. 108.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the other side of the bracket, Mandela pencils in Engl vs. the All Blacks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a satisfied grunt, Mandela steps back from the diagr Things are shaping up nicely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A knock at the door, and Barbara enters, ushering in a GR OF LABOR LEADERS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madiba, this is --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know who this is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beaming, exuding energy we know he doesn't have, Mandela rises to yet another occasion. He strides forward to shak hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome, and thank you for coming such a long way to see me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Monsoon rain batters the bus as it crawls towards KING'S STADIUM, in Durban.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rain, rain, rain. The field is flooding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coach walks in on his team, who are dressed for the match ready to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forty minute postponement. They're trying to clear the field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A HUNDRED ZULU CLEANING LADIES with brooms and squeegees the water off the field. Capacity crowd cheers them on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (This happened. There will be stock footage.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys stretch, jump, try to keep warmed-up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela and a negotiating team are meeting with their opposite numbers from Taiwan. A high-level affair that cannot be interrupted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nonetheless, Mandela takes a discreet look at his watch, we realize that his mind is back home, with the Springbok

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pienaar leads his men out into the rain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A quagmire, despite the efforts of the Zulu ladies. Muddy green and gold against the muddy blue, white and red of France. End of a close game. Both teams are tired, muddy and desperate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The French assault the Springbok try line, wave after wav The Springboks defend valiantly, but slowly go backwards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally, the French score a try -- or do they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE-UP ON THE RUGBY BALL, under a mountain of muddy men the ground three inches outside the try line. 110.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The referee waves off the try.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela flies home, still working intensely with a mixed South African/Taiwanese trade group.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary slips a piece of paper in front of him, discreetly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela's face betrays nothing. But, he gets up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please excuse me for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With Mary leading the way, Mandela goes to the back of th plane, looking grave and leaderly --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- but once he is through the galley curtain, he breaks i a huge smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is very good ... very good! Who is our opponent?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The All Blacks play England tomorrow. Then, we'll know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please make sure that my schedule is clear for the entire match.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Madiba.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON A BIG SCREEN TV in a private banquet room, the Springb team watches the England/All Black semi-final, which the Blacks dominate from beginning to end --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- thanks to the exploits of JONAH LOMU, their unnaturall huge, fast left wing, of Tongan parentage (and unanimous choice for the best player in the entire World Cup). 111.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonah Lomu scores in the first two minutes of the match, first of four tries. He runs through, over, and around hapless defenders. His speed and balance are almost unprecedented in a man his size.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Springboks go quiet as they watch this beating by the Blacks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela watches at home with Barbara and Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's do some work while we watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara resists her natural impulse to work and says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just enjoy the rugby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sound of the match ON THE RADIO of one of the BMWs. Johan Lomu's name in every sentence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the bodyguards are out of the cars, enjoying the wint sunshine as they listen to the match.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, let me understand this. The All Blacks are killing a team that thrashed us last year?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for reminding me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hendrick opens the trunk of their BMW, pulls out a RUGBY BALL, shows it to Linga.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Linga nods. Okay. Throw it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another Lomu try, and a ripple goes through the Springbok 112.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going to have to tackle better than the English, that's for sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TV blares. Barbara does some work. Mandela comes and peek over her shoulder --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are those the judicial appointments for the Free State?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and Barbara shuts the file.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'll keep until after the match.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pile of guns in holsters, on the hood of a BMW. Suit jackets draped over the side mirrors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the wide street, in their shirts and ties, the boys to the ball around. The white bodyguards handle the ball expertly, the black bodyguards for the first time in thei lives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give it a spin when you pass it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kwezi catches the ball, tries to throw it with spin, blow it. The ball bounces crazily all over the street, seems t have a mind of its own as it eludes Kwezi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lomu scores his third try.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much does Lomu weigh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About 120 kilos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit, that's what I weigh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ja, but at least you're slow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As we will discover, the wing is going to have to defend against Lomu.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela isn't watching TV. He's at the window, looking ou at a GAME OF TOUCH RUGBY, taking place on the street outs his house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come and look at this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two mixed teams. Hendrick passes to Linga, who passes bac to Hendrick, who scores.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should've played rugby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They wouldn't let me carry my gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laughter. This scene was unthinkable a year ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara and Mary stand next to Mandela at the window. Mandela's eyes twinkle with pleasure as he hears the laughter. In a way, this small moment already justifies everything he has done. Almost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gives Barbara a sly look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you still think I'm wasting my time with the rugby?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before Barbara can reply, excitement on the TV makes Mand turn away. He looks at the TV just as Lomu scores his fou try, to make it 42 - 15. Mandela shakes his head, awed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara, can you please tell the Minister of Sport that I need a detailed briefing on the All Blacks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara gives Mandela a long look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This rugby, it's still strictly political?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes. Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pienaar hands an envelope to his father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't lose them. I won't be able to get more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Pienaar opens the envelope, pulls out TICKETS TO THE WORLD CUP FINAL. Mr. Pienaar kisses the tickets.

dialogues.speaker: MR. PIENAAR
dialogues.text: Thanks, Francois. (fanning out tickets) Me, mom, Nerine -- wait, and the fourth? Who's it for? 115.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pienaar looks at his father, mischief in his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BMW, Mercedes, BMW, driving from Pretoria to Johannesburg the end of the day. Red winter sunset over the arid Highveld. GO `BOKS, GO AMABOKOBOKO signs, side by side. Chester and Pienaar billboards.

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER OF SPORT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The All Blacks beat Ireland 43 to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Minister of Sport gives Mandela his final briefing. A his side, Barbara thrusts papers in front of Mandela for signature. This continues throughout.

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER OF SPORT
dialogues.text: -- they beat Wales 34 to 9, they beat Japan 145 to 17.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 145 points, in one match?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Linga listens openly.

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER OF SPORT
dialogues.text: It's a new international record. (back to the briefing) They beat Scotland 48 to 30 in the quarter finals. You saw the match with England.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 45 to 29. And it was not that close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They seem unstoppable.

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER OF SPORT
dialogues.text: If opposing teams play them straight up, Jonah Lomu runs wild. If they focus on Lomu, that leaves others free.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And, also, there's the business of the haka. 116.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their Maori war dance. Yes. It's very powerful.

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER OF SPORT
dialogues.text: My sources tell me that half of the All Black matches are won before the first whistle, because of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela peers out of the window at a Springbok billboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are we going to beat them?

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER OF SPORT
dialogues.text: I have the coach's number. You could call him and ask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No ... no. I don't want to break their focus for even a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, how do we win? ON LINGA: an idea occurs to him. A wild idea. He almost turns and blurts it out -- restrains himself.

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER OF SPORT
dialogues.text: Maybe we won't. They're favored two-to-one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madiba, we've already exceeded all expectations. On and off the field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not enough. Not now. Not so close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This country is hungry for greatness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara pushes another paper in front of Mandela. He sign it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The coach, the manager and Pienaar gather for a final briefing in the coach's spartan office. 117.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's the feeling in the dressing room?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Calm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Lomu? Are they talking about him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pienaar shrugs -- of course. Coach grins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody gives us a bloody chance. I like that. It plays into their one weakness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both Pienaar and the manager look at the coach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their vanity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're already counting the win. But they want to win with style, the way they won all their other matches. They want to show the world how beautiful All Black rugby is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just want to show the bloody world how hard we tackle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pienaar's up for that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish tomorrow was already here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason wishes tomorrow was already over. He goes through h plans, his check lists for the tenth time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sighs, tries to roll the tension out of his shoulders, gives up. He leaves the office. 118.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cops at their posts. Jason walks alone through the tunnel until he comes to a field entrance. He goes to the edge, looks out at the dimly lit field, trying to imagine tomor

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from behind him) Come on, man. There's nothing more you can do today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason turns to Etienne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have I ever mentioned to you that I hate rugby?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once or twice, yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just want to get him through tomorrow, safely. That's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We all do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A look between the two men: they are united. They have co a long way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As in Cape Town, Pienaar stares out into the night, pensively. Preoccupied.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So preoccupied, that when Nerine enters quietly, he hardl turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I brought one of your mom's protein shakes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pienaar nods, thanks. Nerine puts the protein shake down. She tries to read Pienaar's mood, see what he needs from at this moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thinking about tomorrow? 119.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, tomorrow's taken care of, one way or another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pienaar turns to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm thinking about how you spend 30 years in a tiny cell, but come out ready to forgive the people who put you there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have seen that solitary shape under the blankets befor We have seen the clock on the bedside table change from 4 to 5:00 before. We have seen Mandela's eyes open, immediately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But we have never seen Mandela roll over and go back to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two BWMs wait faithfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Linga looks at his watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hendrick does the same. Gets out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Linga gets out, meets Hendrick at the gate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be an even bigger day if we actually won. 120.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then, they both look at their watches again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They share a worried look. Linga reaches for his radio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela's bedroom door is opened from outside the room. Light from the hallway hits the bed. Mandela looks very still under the covers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary peers in, concern wiping away sleep. She sees Mandel lying there. Mary tiptoes in, concern growing, until she stands over Mandela --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- who opens his eyes without moving otherwise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can a man not sleep in, when he has a big day ahead of him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary's voice on Linga's radio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, thanks. Out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Linga lowers his radio, embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's sleeping in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Linga and Hendrick stand at the gate for a moment, then t to head back to their respective cars. Linga pauses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had an idea. About today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a crazy idea. 121.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, don't worry, man. I already know you're crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela eats breakfast -- porridge and fresh fruit -- and looks over the newspaper headlines, all screaming about today's World Cup final.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doorbell rings, and he pauses, listens to the sound o voices at the door -- then the sound of heavy footsteps approaching through the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela wipes his mouth and waits. Linga and Hendrick app in the doorway. They look even bigger indoors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning, boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LINGA & HENDRICK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning, Madiba.  MANDELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Linga hesitates -- until Hendrick gives him a (for Hendri discreet nudge.  HENDRICK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Linga had an idea, sir.  CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary walks briskly to her car, gets in and drives towards opening gate, fast.  CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Linga and Hendrick watch as Mary drives away. 122.    HENDRICK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you've done it.  CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As in Cape Town, the Springboks jog through the streets. in Cape Town, cars toot their horns, people cheer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the crowd running with them is twice as large as it w in Cape Town -- and twice as black.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This crowd shows that the Springboks really do have the support of the whole country now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the `boks rumble past, newspaper vendors, gardeners, pharmacy delivery men on small motorbikes abandon their t and run alongside the team.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pienaar turns to look at one of his teammates, grins, get grin in return.  CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason addresses his entire team (minus Linga), plus assor POLICE OFFICERS.  JASON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tickets sold out long before the team became so popular. So it's not exactly going to be the rainbow nation out there. That's the reality. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The President will greet the players before the match, he'll present the trophy after the match. He'll be exposed to 62,000 people, twice. He'll be on TV, live, all over the world. (expressing his deepest FEAR)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All it takes is one idiot trying to make a statement, or one crazy fool who thinks he hears god speaking to him over the radio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the cops smiles at that. 123.    JASON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's happened before! (SUPER INTENSE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But not today. Not on our watch. Not today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The security boys are fired up.  CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is hours before the match, but every entrance to Ellis Park stadium is chaotic with people, cars, face painters, flag sellers, fruit vendors. Cops everywhere, and everywh outnumbered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the crowd outside, WE FIND SIPHO, collecting empty bot from trash cans, for recycling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason was right about the demographics of the crowd: whit khaki-clad, quite a few old South African flags among the of new flags. Springbok colors everywhere. We may even se the FOUR BOERE from the Lions debacle earlier.  FACE PAINTER (TO BOERE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Face flag?  BOER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bugger off!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellis Park isn't exactly the Rainbow Nation today.

dialogues.speaker: BOLAND BOTHA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We're at Ellis Park on this historic day, where, even this early, crowd excitement is at fever PITCH --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boland does another live remote. FANS CHEER AND WAVE behi HIM  BOLAND BOTHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- because their beloved green and gold have somehow managed to exceed all expectations.  CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A luxury bus pulls away from the hotel, with a FULL POLIC ESCORT, LIGHTS ON, SIRENS BLARING.

dialogues.speaker: BOLAND BOTHA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But now they come up against a team that is unlike any other they have played.  CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With that inward look of boxers before a big fight, the Springboks begin the journey to the stadium.

dialogues.speaker: BOLAND BOTHA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: These All Blacks are possibly one of the greatest international sides ever, with a player in Jonah Lomu who is as dominant as any this correspondent has ever seen.  CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela's Mercedes exits his gate, BMWs fore and aft.

dialogues.speaker: BOLAND BOTHA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: To lose to them is no disgrace. To lose to them in the finals is, in fact, an honor.  CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tight on Mandela's face, absolutely expressionless. His g face.

dialogues.speaker: BOLAND BOTHA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I say this with absolutely no negativity. I simply want to save people from the heartbreak of unrealistic expectations.  CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back to Boland's live remote.  BOLAND BOTHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, take a reality check, sit back and share an afternoon with one billion fellow fans around the world. And as you do, feel a special pride in having made it this far. This is Boland Botha, signing off and sitting back at Ellis Park.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huge crowd now, all around the TV truck, streaming in.  CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Driving down a secure access lane, the Springbok bus and police escort approach Ellis Park.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And pass Sipho, who stares up at them from the sidewalk.  CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys are very quiet -- until the sheer spectacle gets them. Then, the first nerves hit. You can tell in the way they look at each other, the way they swallow.  CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela's convoy pulls up at a secure entrance.  CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stadium almost full. Crowd noise a dull roar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ABOVE THE SPRINGBOK BENCH, near the field, we find Nerine Mr. and Mrs. Pienaar ... and Eunice, as they take their seats. Pienaar got the fourth ticket for her. 126.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eunice turns to Mrs. Pienaar.  EUNICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's Mr. Francois doing now?  CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All dressed, all warmed up, the Springboks are quiet, introspective. Everything that should be said has been sa This is the calm before the storm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (NOTE that almost every player wears bandages, or braces, is injured in some way.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pienaar is not in the room.  CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dressed in his rugby togs, Pienaar sneaks up the ramp to edge of the field, takes a peek out of the tunnel --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and is blown away by the magnitude of it all.  CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vast city seen from the air. Zero in on Ellis Park.  CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANOTHER ANGLE of a SOUTH AFRICAN AIRWAYS 747 flying over city, in the direction of Ellis Park.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CO-PILOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Final approach, Captain.  CAPTAIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let it be noted that I'm taking control of the aircraft.
CAPTAIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I assume full responsibility for what happens from now on.  CO-PILOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duly noted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The captain drops the nose of the 747 towards Ellis Park.  CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every seat full. Almost every seat filled by a big white man. Excitement unbearable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason stalks the runways between the seating sections, hi in the stadium. Binoculars around his neck, radio in hand

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something catches his eye. Something in the air. Jason lifts his binoculars to his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: POV THROUGH BINOCULARS -- the 747 is heading right for th stadium.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason lowers his binoculars. He frowns -- more puzzled th alarmed. (This is pre-9/11.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lifts his radio to his mouth.  JASON (INTO RADIO)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you see that jet, to the east?  CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Etienne, in another part of the stadium, looks eastwards sees it.  ETIENNE (INTO RADIO)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did they get clearance for this?  CUT TO:  JASON (INTO RADIO)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not from us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The 747 gets closer, fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason is hit by a horrible thought. 128.    JASON (INTO RADIO)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is he?  LINGA (ON RADIO)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason finds the VIP box, looks out at the 747 --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and realizes that the jet is heading straight at that of the stadium.  JASON (INTO RADIO)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get him out of there. Now.  CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela is not in his seat. Linga turns. Hendrick points the closed door of the VIP bathroom.  LINGA (INTO RADIO)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No time.  CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing Jason can do about it but hold his breath as --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The captain drops the 747 even lower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason has to fight down the impulse to flee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone in the VIP box sees the jet. They all stand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The 747 nose appears over the rim of the stadium.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAPTAIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Full throttle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain and co-pilot go full throttle, yank the 747 strai upwards.  CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ALMIGHTY ROAR OF FULL THROTTLES fills the stadium, as 747 passes less than 200 feet overhead --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- so that everyone can read the huge letters painted on bottom of the wings:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (This really happened.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JASON NEARLY FAINTS with relief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Linga and Hendrick share a look. They have just had a bru with the unthinkable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DRESSING ROOM VIBRATES with the roar ... 130.    SPRINGBOK WING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell was that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... which slowly fades ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... leaving only the background roar of the revved up cro

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys jog in place, dying for the release of rugby. Pienaar appears to be praying, silently.  CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The REFEREE walks off the field, into the tunnel, stands there for a moment, then raises his whistle to his mouth blows a LONG, ECHOING BLAST --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- which is the signal to come to the field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cop opens the door, throws down a full parade ground salute as Pienaar leads his men out of the dressing room.  PIENAAR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Breathe, boys. Breathe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WITH THE `BOKS, we head down the hallway, down some stair the tunnel onto the field --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- where the referee holds his hand up like a traffic cop keeping the boys in a line in the tunnel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they wait, they hear the CRUNCHING APPROACH OF BIG MEN CLEATS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Down the opposite stairway come THE ALL BLACKS. This is t first time we have seen them in the flesh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huge men, black on black uniforms, arrogant. Been here before, done this before. The best in the world, expectin nothing but the best from the day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They ignore the Springboks, dismiss them, line up next to them in the tunnel. 131.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SOUND OF THIRTY MEN JOGGING IN PLACE in their cleats, the concrete, sounds like a drum roll before a medieval battle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Springbok wing sneaks a peek at JONAH LOMU.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The biggest, fastest wing ever. Even bigger looking in th confined space. Bigger than the Springbok wing, bigger th any of the Springbok backs, bigger than most of the Sprin forwards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The referee nods to both captains, turns, and leads them the field --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- where the already-whipped up crowd goes crazy, as both teams sprint onto the field and go through their brief wa up ritual.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WE FOCUS ON THE CROWD, focus on how white and old South Africa most of them are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The referee blows his whistle again, and both teams assem in a line, facing each other. Glaring like boxers across immaculate green grass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seen only in silhouette, Mandela walks down the tunnel. H is flanked by Jason, The Minister of Sport and the Presid of SA Rugby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Linga, as always, has Mandela's back. Plus Hendrick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela emerges into daylight, wearing not a suit, not a Madiba shirt --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- he is wearing Francois Pienaar's green and gold number rugby jersey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On his head is THE SPRINGBOK CAP given to him by the team CAPE TOWN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd catches its breath. This is unprecedented, shocking ... and brilliant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Springboks digest this extraordinary display of suppo 132.    SPRINGBOK HOOKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (murmuring to Pienaar) The All Blacks won't like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pienaar nods, eyes glinting. Mandela is giving them an ed

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he walks towards the waiting teams, Mandela lifts the Springbok cap high, waves it, and fires his famous, beautiful, huge, African smile at the crowd --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- who roar and stand, slowly, and start chanting, slowly  CROWD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nelson ... Nelson ... Nelson ... NELSON ... NELSON ... NELSON ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 63 000 South Africans, chanting as one.  CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALL ACROSS SOUTH AFRICA, THE CHANT ECHOES through EMPTY STREETS. Not a soul, not a car to be seen. Everyone is inside, watching TV.  CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CROWD

dialogues.speaker: ... NELSON ... NELSON ... NELSON
dialogues.text: ... etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela shakes hands with the Springboks, who are brimmin with pride. Mandela shakes Chester Williams' hand with special energy.  MANDELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so glad you're here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chester beams.  CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IN THE STANDS, EUNICE ULULATES, loud African warrior woma call. Mr. Pienaar looks at her, shocked. Looks at her as person for the first time, maybe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eunice ululates again.  CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON THE FIELD, Mandela shakes hands with the All Blacks, w as predicted, don't like his partisan clothing. Mandela looks up at Jonah Lomu.  MANDELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Jonah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lomu looks down at Mandela, eyes glowing with aggression

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and suddenly, he bares his tattooed Tongan tongue in a FIERCE WAR CRY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As do the rest of the All Blacks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WE HAVE SEGUED TO THE FAMOUS HAKA, a Maori war dance that tells an opponent they're going have their daughters stol their wives ravaged and their brains eaten right out of t skulls with a sharpened tea spoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is abundantly clear why, as the Minister of Sports tol Mandela, half of the All Blacks matches are won before th whistle blows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is very intimidating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Especially because, this day, the All Blacks push the hak closer and closer to the Springboks --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- who do not back down. In fact, they close ranks and advance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Major, major international smackdown. This is not fake. T emotions, the aggression are real.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON MANDELA, whose diplomatic mask slips a little showing warrior's glitter in his eyes. He wants to respond, primally. His fists clench at his side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The HAKA ENDS with a fearsome, guttural Maori yell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON THE SPRINGBOKS, massed together, faces red with emotio pulses racing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela takes a deep breath in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then the boys answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With, of course, a terrorist anthem of their own: NKOSI SIKELEL' IAFRIKA. 134.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pienaar starts it.  PIENAAR NKOSI --  ALL SPRINGBOKS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- SIKELEL' IAFRIKA etc ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With decent pronunciation, with full fervor and heart, TH BOYS ROAR THE ANTHEM back at the All Blacks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd joins them. "Nkosi" roars through the stadium, through the nation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON MANDELA: his heart swells, as he sings with his people  CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON JASON, who stands surrounded by his former enemies sin the song that kept him -- kept all of them -- going throu the apartheid years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In this stadium, at this moment, all hostility, all fear, a thing of the past.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tension finally goes out of Jason's shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON JASON'S FACE, close to tears, as NKOSI slowly fades.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Mandela said -- a very inspirational song.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BEGIN HEARTBEAT OVER. Is that a heartbeat, or an African drum?  CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON THE FIELD, the All Black fly half tees up the ball, fo kick off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the fly half back-pedals slowly, and pauses in readine waiting for the whistle --  CUT AWAY:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TO RAINBOW NATION FACES, poised all over South Africa, WATCHING ON TV and IN THE STANDS. Heart/drumbeat over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The last face is Sipho's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd noise spills out of the stadium behind Sipho. 135.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A RADIO PLAYS NEARBY, tuned to the game. The radio is in cop car, manned by TWO BEEFY WHITE COPS. As the crowd noi rises, Sipho edges closer to the cops. They eye him out.  CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela front and center. Minister of Sport to his right, Prime Minister of New Zealand to his left, President of S Rugby next to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both using all their diplomatic skills to stay cool.  MANDELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to NZ P.M.) Perhaps we should make a small wager?

dialogues.speaker: NEW ZEALAND P.M.
dialogues.text: All your gold, for all our sheep?  MANDELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was thinking more along the lines of a case of wine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behind Mandela, Linga and Hendrick suppress grins. They a outwardly professional -- but bursting with excitement.  CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The referee blows his whistle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The All Black fly half boots the ball towards the Springb charges after it, along with the rest of the All Blacks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Game on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have only seen snippets of rugby, so far. And mostly f a somewhat polite distance -- the usual distance of TV coverage. Say, at closest, the referee's point of view.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not now. Not for the climax. We experience this beautiful piece of mayhem up close and personal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're inside the heaving scrums. We are the ball. We see the way cleats leave a pattern of round white dimples on abused skin, which quickly turn to purple as they fill wi subcutaneous blood. 136.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We feel a tackle in our own spine; we see teeth sink into flesh in the intimacy of a loose scrum; we feel a hard fi smacking us again and again in the hot privacy of a rolli maul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For this is not a pretty match, not for one moment -- jus the Springbok coach wanted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This match is all about a less talented team stifling the best team in the world by sheer determination and fitness

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is about the Springboks applying continuous, unrelen pressure, and forcing the vaunted All Black attack into making mistakes. Lots of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dropped balls, errant passes, knock-ons. No fluency of movement, no electric building of momentum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because of one thing: tackling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tackling and tackling and tackling again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The first time Lomu touches the ball, the stadium, the na holds its breath --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- until the Springbok wing scythes into him at thigh hei wraps him up and brings him down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The second time Lomu gets the ball he is brought down fro behind by Pienaar, with a picture perfect tackle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can cut away to the faces of the spectators when we wa from Mandela to Nerine to Sipho and on and on, all over t country. But, in truth, our attention belongs on the fiel

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON PIENAAR, continually exhorting his men, leading by example, wreaking havoc in the All Black backfield.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON LOMU, who always seems just one broken tackle away fro running one in -- except that there are no broken tackles

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON THIRTY BIG, STRONG, BATTLE-SCARRED MEN, who have devot their entire lives to this moment. They are not playing f money. They are playing for pride, for their countries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outdated notions. We miss them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No tries are scored in the Final. The two fly halves matc each other, penalty goal for penalty goal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With each made kick, the goal posts shrink for the next. penalty goals are unchallenged. It is up to the kicker to make them or fail. That is pressure. 137.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The score is 6 - 6 when, just before half time, the Sprin fly half takes a long, perfect pass from the scrum half, with the All Black defenders looming, kicks a drop goal through the uprights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Springboks lead 9 - 6. A tight match.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So tight, in fact, that there is only one score in the se half -- an All Black drop goal that levels the score at 9 9.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Until right before the end of the match, when the All Bla camp in the Springbok half.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The scrum half sends a long, spiralling pass to the fly h who is in perfect position to go for a drop goal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kick soars into the air, high and straight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 43 million South Africans hold their breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All around the world, fans lean forward on their chairs. This will be the decisive blow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the kick just goes wide. Relief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The referee blows his whistle to signal the end of regulation. Both teams are spent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LINGA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happens now?  HENDRICK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Extra time. Twenty minutes.  LINGA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think I can take it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one can. Mandela paces. Everyone is drained.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sipho leans on the cop car, listening to the radio. He an the two cops suck nervously on sodas.  CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two sets of bruised, bleeding, exhausted, cramping men fa each other for the extra time kick off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pienaar turns to his men.  PIENAAR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's the fittest team on this field?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The answer lies in their eyes: they are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An All Black penalty goal makes it 12 - 9 almost immediat

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Springbok penalty goal answers. 12 - 12.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seven minutes from the end of extra time, the Springboks a scrum deep in All Blacks territory.  PIENAAR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep it here. Run it forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The scrum goes down, wheels a little.

dialogues.speaker: SPRINGBOK FLY HALF
dialogues.text: Francois! Pienaar turns his head. The fly half taps his own chest: give me the ball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pienaar hesitates, then nods to the scrum half: give him ball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ball goes into the scrum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ball works its way back through the feet of the eight Springbok forwards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The scrum half gathers it, spins it out to the fly half -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- who takes one step to his left and KICKS A DROP GOAL h into the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ball soaring past a backdrop of open mouths. Higher than uprights ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... but through them nonetheless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Springboks 15 - 12 All Blacks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An entire nation jumps to its feet. 139.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone is on their feet in the press box.  MANDELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long before the end?

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER OF SPORT
dialogues.text: Seven minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They turn out to be the longest seven minutes in Mandela' life. In every South African's life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is where we fold the Rainbow Nation into the rugby match, fully.

dialogues.speaker: BETWEEN PEOPLE ALL OVER SOUTH AFRICA, AND THE RU
dialogues.text: as we show the whole nation wanting exactly the same thin the same time. Faces, postures, eyes are identical, no matter where they are, who they are, what color they are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (It would be nice if we used all the faces we've already away to throughout this story.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The All Blacks attack desperately. The Springboks tackle tackle and tackle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON PIENAAR, totally spent but dragging himself to his fee for another tackle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He glances over at the referee, makes another tackle --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- looks over at the referee --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- the referee puts his hands on his whistle --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- another tackle, another look --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- the referee lifts the whistle to his lips --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- another tackle, another look --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- the REFEREE BLOWS THE FINAL WHISTLE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Springboks have won. 140.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pandemonium on the field, pandemonium in the stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason is hugged by an ecstatic boer (Jason is not a hugge  CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Pienaar and Nerine are in tears. Mr. Pienaar hugs a shocked Eunice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pandemonium in the VIP box. Mandela shakes hands with everyone he can find. It is way too loud to say anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hendrick and Linga almost hug. Almost. They shake hands with total joy and engagement, whack each other on the shoulder.  CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sipho toi-tois next to the cop car (a township war dance, very political). The two cops toi-toi with him.  CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AROUND THE NATION, an EPIDEMIC OF HUGGING begins. This spills out onto the streets later, but for now, let's restrict this to the people who've been watching the matc together.  CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Springboks say a prayer on the field. Pienaar kneels the middle, leading the prayer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behind them, a WORK CREW ASSEMBLES A PORTABLE PODIUM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At "Amen", Pienaar's men lift him to his feet, then onto their shoulders. 141.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd roars again and again as PIENAAR TAKES A VICTOR LAP on the shoulders of the men he has led through thick thin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tears stream down his face, through his unstoppable grin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they near the podium, the team is intercepted by a new crew and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- none other then BOLAND BOTHA.  BOLAND BOTHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Francois ... a few words ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The interview booms through the PA system. Pienaar just n -- he isn't about to spoil the moment by reacting to this buffoon.  BOLAND BOTHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... great game, but I don't think you could've done it without the amazing support of these 63,000 South Africans --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Francois grabs the mike from Boland.  PIENAAR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into mike, words booming) We didn't have the support of 63,000 South Africans today. We had the support of 42 million South Africans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd roars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Springbok manager grabs Pienaar's shoulder, points.  SPRINGBOK MANAGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're waiting for you over there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pienaar turns, looks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela waits at the podium, eyes alight with joy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In front of him is the WILLIAM WEBB ELLIS TROPHY, a big g confection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their eyes meet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their eyes stay locked as Pienaar fights his way through press, the officials, his own team, to the podium. 142.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela holds out his hand. Pienaar takes it. Big hands, one black, one white, one with bruises visible, one with lifetime of bruises implied.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both wearing the NUMBER 6 SPRINGBOK JERSEY.  MANDELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Francois, I want to thank you most sincerely for what you have done to our country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pienaar shakes his head.  PIENAAR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. President, I want to thank you for what you have done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eyes lock again, for just a moment, blue eyes, brown eyes African eyes, both.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then PIENAAR RAISES THE TROPHY HIGH. A very tradition sports hero's moment, richly deserved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Real gold, against the green of the battered field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But that is not the real prize.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The prize is what happens next, all over the nation.  DISSOLVE TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALL OVER SOUTH AFRICA, people spill out into the streets, celebrate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Utter joy, everywhere, as black and white, servants and employers, strangers, enemies, foreigners are swept up in love and happiness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People who have been suspicious of each other, hated each other, feared each other all their lives ... they hug eac other on this day.  DISSOLVE TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Housewives, gardeners, cops, kids dance in the middle of street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A car horn beeps politely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BMW, Mercedes, BMW come slowly down the street. 143.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd begins to dance and ululate as they part to let convoy through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Linga in front. Mandela is alone in the back seat. He loo out at his people as they cheer him through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He also looks exhausted. Spent. None of that shining life force that makes him so big.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JASON (INTO RADIO)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This route's too crowded. We're changing to route B.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The convoy switches to another street --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- which is just as crowded as the first, with happy Sout Africans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is as if every single person in the Rainbow Nation wan to celebrate together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JASON (INTO RADIO)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Change to route C.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The convoy switches to yet another street --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- to no avail. South Africa is literally dancing in the streets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela leans forward, taps Linga on the shoulder. 144.    MANDELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell Jason it's all right. There's no hurry.  LINGA (INTO RADIO)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madiba says no need to hurry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason nods, puts down his radio, settles back with a deep sigh. So do the rest of the boys in the car. This day is almost over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Etienne, Hendrick loosen their ties, bask in the feeling. Hendrick looks out at the rolling street party -- and sha his head in amazement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: President Nelson Rolihlahla Mandela undoes the top button his rugby jersey, settles back with a deep sigh --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and drives home through a nation that has begun the process of forgiving itself. His nation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GO IN ON MANDELA'S FACE as it settles into the now-famili sphinx-like mask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Except for his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mandela's eyes glow with deep joy and satisfaction as he moves slowly through a moment in history that he has work for, all his life.

dialogues.speaker: SLOWLY TO BLACK.
dialogues.text: THE END
